headline: Cristiano Ronaldo can't hide his true feelings towards Man Utd after Erik ten Hag feud
body: Manchester United favourite Cristiano Ronaldo was sent a birthday message on social media from his former club - even though he left Old Trafford in acrimonious circumstances
Cristiano Ronaldo may have left Manchester United for the second time under a cloud back in November 2022, the multi-time Ballon d'Or winner still holds the club dear to his heart.
Ronaldo, 39, returned to Old Trafford back in the summer of 2021 after spending six years playing under Sir Alex Ferguson at the start of his career, but his second coming was short-lived.

Despite plundering 24 goals in 38 matches in all competitions during the 2021/22 campaign, Ronaldo was given a reduced bit-part role following the arrival of Erik ten Hag before their relationship completely disintegrated.

Ronaldo would end up terminating his contract early after reaching a mutual agreement with United back in November 2022. However, his association with the club remains to this day and the Premier League outfit were quick to send a message of support to the Portuguese superstar on his 39th birthday.
The message from United, which was shared on Instagram alongside the 'Viva Ronaldo' chant, was given a seal of approval by the man himself, who liked the post on his own account.

Ronaldo, who currently plays for Al-Nassr in the Saudi Pro League, claimed he felt "betrayed" by the club and slammed Ten Hag during an explosive interview with Piers Morgan shortly before his exit was confirmed after growing disillusioned with life at Old Trafford under the Dutchman.

Given the nature of his comments, his departure came as no surprise when it was announced a few days later. Reacting to the news, Ronaldo issued a statement which read: "Following conversations with Manchester United we have mutually agreed to end our contract early.

"I love Manchester United and I love the fans, that will never ever change. However, it feels like the right time for me to seek a new challenge. I wish the team every success for the remainder of the season and for the future."

Since quitting the Premier League, Ronaldo has plundered 44 goals in 50 games in Saudi Arabia for Al-Nassr, who are currently vying for the Saudi Pro League title. They are currently second, seven points behind Al-Hilal, who are unbeaten so far this term.
In total, Ronaldo scored 145 goals for Manchester United in the 345 appearances he made across his two spells at the club.

headline: Rio Ferdinand warns Premier League stars don't have 'safe space' to come out as gay
body: Former England captain and Man Utd defender Rio Ferdinand says it's still 'inevitable they would get hammered by people'
Rio Ferdinand says football is still not set up to provide the support a Premier League star would need to be openly gay.

The former England captain added that although attitudes have changed for the better in recent decades, top flight male players would face abuse for coming out. Rio, 45, who used homophobic language in the past, also said that what was classed as dressing room banter in his playing days was brutal.

Asked why there are no openly gay players in the top flight in England, Rio said: “I don’t think football has put together the infrastructure for a safe space for a person to come out. There’s a lot of uncontrollable like fans, social media, forums, where it’s inevitable that they’ll get hammered by people.”
For a documentary fronted by TV presenter Rylan Clark, Rio is quizzed about jokingly calling DJ Chris Moyles a “faggot” on Radio 1 in 2006. Rylan asks: “It got you in a little bit of hot water?”

Rio replies: “It didn’t at the time. I think Ofcom got two complaints. That was the way the changing room and we were. It was brutal. If you were to jump back in time and be in that changing room, the language used then would [now] be getting people cancelled left, right and centre. It was seen as normal.”

The former Manchester United and Leeds defender, who played from the mid-90s to 2015, adds: “I’ve been fortunate because my sister is gay. I made her listen to [the Radio 1 clip]. And I was… embarrassed. I’ll do everything I can to make her feel comfortable and acknowledge I was part of a culture that was very wrong, and actually society wasn’t where it is today.”

Rylan, 35, says it “doesn’t make sense” that there are no openly gay footballers in the Premier League. He then meets former Aston Villa, West Ham and Everton player Thomas Hitzlsperger, who is openly gay in retirement. The German international says he never considered coming out during his career because he was “terrified” of the consequences. Thomas, 41, said: “It was the dressing room.

“We had conversations in the dressing room, and somebody started a conversation saying, ‘What if we had a gay team-mate? What would you do?’. Then suddenly, players had their opinion on it. Some of the comments were really terrifying. I thought, ‘If they know I am gay would they really do this, what they just said like, “I wouldn’t want to shower with that player, I wouldn’t want to get changed with a player”?’.

“More things were said which I wouldn’t want to say in public. So it wasn’t the media. It wasn’t the fans. It was the dressing room. Every [day] you change with the players, you shower. And if somebody is uncomfortable, you unsettle the whole dressing room. It has an effect on training and games. So that responsibility I didn’t want to take.” After talking to openly gay players in the lower leagues and the women’s game, Rylan says he hopes coming out won’t be a big deal for Premier League stars in future.
He adds: “I cannot wait until we get to a point where I haven’t got to do this documentary.”

headline: Man Utd outcast Donny van de Beek suffers humbling new low weeks after transfer exit
body: Manchester United flop Donny van de Beek has had to deal with another career set-back as loan club Eintracht Frankfurt have left the Dutchman out of their Europa Conference League squad
Despite only joining Eintracht Frankfurt from parent club Manchester United last month, Donny van de Beek has already been omitted from the German side's Europa Conference League squad.

The Netherlands international upped sticks to Frankfurt for the remainder of the campaign at the start of the January transfer window. It had been hoped that the loan switch would kickstart a flatlining career after more than three years of sitting on the bench for the Red Devils.

However, Van de Beek has hardly hit the ground running with the Bundesliga outfit. In just his third appearance for the club, he was hauled off at half-time before being left on the bench for the entirety of Saturday's 2-0 defeat by FC Koln.

Things have since gone from bad to worse for Van de Beek, who has been left out of Eintracht's 25-man squad for the Europa Conference League knockout rounds. UEFA's rules state that clubs can only make three changes to their team for the next stage of the competition.

Sasa Kalajdzic, Hugo Ekitike and Philipp Max - other January signings made by the club have been named instead of Van de Beek. Though it didn't cost much in terms of a loan fee to bring the Dutchman to the club, Eintracht are covering the bulk of his £125,000-a-week wages.

Within his loan contract is an option to buy for a fee that would pocket United just shy of £12million, marking a steep loss considering they forked out £40m to sign him from Ajax back in 2020. In that time, he's managed to make less than 30 starts, meaning he will forever be viewed as one of the most underwhelming Red Devils signings of recent memory.

Speaking in December, Van de Beek was clearly champing at the bit to force through a United exit because of the lack of game-time on offer. His prolonged misery under Erik ten Hag came as a surprise to some, given it was the man that currently occupies the Old Trafford hot-seat that got the best out of the midfielder at Ajax.
Discussing his United failings, Van de Beek explained: "I had hoped for more games when I was playing well, so you get into a flow. But you have to deal with more factors.

"Everyone wants to make United successful again, but they are not succeeding - and it's hard to put your finger on it. But I am bursting with energy now that I am fit again and I am really training like an animal. The time has come to make a different choice."
A different choice was made, but it has unfortunately produced the same outcome for Van de Beek.

headline: Rasmus Hojlund picks dream Man Utd 5-a-side team with Cristiano Ronaldo verdict clear
body: Rasmus Hojlund has been starting to make a name for himself after a £72m summer move to Manchester United, and the Danish international as given his opinion on the club's greats
Manchester United striker Rasmus Hojlund found a spot for Cristiano Ronaldo in his dream United five-a-side team, but there was no space for all-time top scorer Wayne Rooney

Ronaldo had two stints at Old Trafford, winning the Ballon d'Or and Champions League in his first. The Portugal star was less successful in his second stint, and left by mutual agreement before his contract with the Old Trafford club was up.

Denmark international Hojlund was brought in over the summer to fill the gap left by Ronaldo's departure. The former Atalanta man started slowly after his £72m summer switch, but has found form since the turn of the year with four goals in as many games.

Hojlund was a United supporter as a boy, starting to follow the club in the first decade of the century, and this has been reflected in his picks for his five-aside team. With only five spots available, though, some big names had to miss out.

Speaking to The United Stand, Hojlund made goalkeeper and compatriot Peter Schmeichel his first pick. "I need to put Peter in goal. Peter is Danish," he said. "Peter won everything here. Peter is a legend here but is also a legend in Denmark because he won the Euros for us."
With only one spot in defence, Hojlund was made to choose between Rio Ferdinand and Nemanja Vidic. In the end, the English half of the 2007-08 Champions League winning partnership got the nod.
"I need to put Rio in there because he's very memorable to me," Hojlund continued. "I would love to put Vidic in there, but I can only have one defender.

Only a handful of United players won the Champions League in both 1999 and 2008, and two of them make it into Hojlund's team. Both are academy graduates who spent their entire careers at Old Trafford, with Ryan Giggs and Paul Scholes getting the nod in the midfield spots
"I want to put Ryan Giggs in there, Paul Scholes and then Cristiano up front," Hojlund explained. That means no Rooney, and also no room for former United skipper Roy Keane, among others.

Back in the summer, Hojlund told club media the 2008 Champions League final success was one of his first football memories that stuck with him. He also explained the role his dad played in getting him into football, leading to him choosing United as his team.

"My father pushed it over my head, and I started following everybody around the club and of course, I was very into Premier League football and everything around it," Hojlund said. “So, I kept watching, and of course, Cristiano [Ronaldo] was my idol when he was playing back then, so I kept following him and of course kept following Manchester United.”

headline: Christian Eriksen 'could leave Man Utd THIS week' after secret transfer talks emerge
body: Manchester United midfielder Christian Eriksen has been attracting interest from overseas and could yet be lured away from Old Trafford ahead of the Turkish transfer deadline
Christian Eriksen has held talks with Galatasaray over a potential transfer away from Manchester United, with the Turkish transfer window open still open until later this week.
Eriksen, 31, joined the Red Devils on a free transfer from Brentford in the summer of 2022 and has gone on to make over 50 appearances under Erik ten Hag.
The Denmark international has started just three matches in the Premier League since mid-November, though, due to a combination of injuries and the emergence of midfield prodigy Kobbie Mainoo.

The winter transfer window for English clubs shut last week with United opting against making any signings. A handful of fringe players did depart - and Eriksen could join them with Turkish clubs still able to sign players until February 9.

According to Fotomac, Galatasaray have held 'secret talks' with United and Eriksen over a potential loan deal for the playmaker. The deal would include an option to make the switch permanent in the summer.
The report goes on to outline that if the clubs cannot strike an agreement for Eriksen to join before the Turkish deadline later this week than a "promise" will be made ahead of a summer move.

Eriksen's current contract at Old Trafford runs until the summer of 2025 but the former Tottenham and Inter Milan star hinted back in October that he wasn't totally happy with his standing in the squad after being dropped by Ten Hag.

“I think you should ask the coach what he thinks," Eriksen told Danish outlet Ekstrabladet when he was asked about his absence from the team. “We have been hit hard by injuries in defence. We have simply conceded too many goals. I was sick last week, but I’m doing fine. I don’t have any flaws. The body feels good and of course I want to play every game.
“But if you have seen the matches yourself, you may also see that [Ten Hag] plays with slightly different types than me,” he added shortly before competing in a round of Euro 2024 qualifiers.

Mainoo, 18, has enhanced his growing reputation with a number of fine displays in recent weeks and started alongside Casemiro in Sunday's 3-0 win over West Ham. Scott McTominay, who came in the match, has also leapfrogged Eriksen in the Old Trafford pecking order.

headline: Sir Alex Ferguson breaks record after £633k deal for Cheltenham Festival hope
body: Former Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson will share Caldwell Potter with three close friends following tragic death of Hermes Allen at weekend
Sir Alex Ferguson is to become one of the new owners of a leading Cheltenham Festival hope.
The ex-Manchester United manager will share Caldwell Potter with friends Ged Mason. John Hales and Peter Done after the jumper fetched a record sum at auction on Monday.

Trained by Gordon Elliott, Caldwell Potter announced himself as one of the top novice hurdlers in training after winning at Grade 1 level in December and is as low as 8-1 to score at the Cheltenham Festival in March.
He was one of 29 horses to go under the hammer at Tattersalls in Ireland after  owners Andy and Gemma Brown abruptly announced they were taking a break from the sport  following recent horse deaths.
Amid a packed auction ring, bloodstock agent Anthony Bromley secured the horse when bidding €740,000 [£633,000] to smash the record paid for a jumps horse at public auction. Elliot was underbidder.

He will join the yard of 14-time champion jump trainer Paul Nicholls who lost Grade 1-winner Hermes Alllen to a fatal injury in a fall at Sandown on Saturday. Ferguson, Mason and Hales were also involved in that horse.
Bromley told Tattersalls: "I don't feel great about taking the horse out of Gordon Elliott's yard. He's done so well with this horse.

"But this is business and you've got to do the best for your clients and when I saw the horse coming up for sale there was only one phone call I made and it was to John Hales. He's been a client of mine for many, many years.
"I bought him for a little partnership they've got together, four guys, John Hales, Ged Mason, Sir Alex Ferguson and Peter Done."
He went on., "He doesn't have to go and run at Cheltenham I believe. It could be that he needs the time to settle in and go to Aintree.
"But really we bought him to be a steeplechaser because he's got the pedigree for a three mile Gold Cup I think. He's such an exciting horse for the longer term. "
On a tragic weekend for the Nicholls stable, the death was announced of a member of their staff  Keagan Kirkby who died in a fall  while riding in a point-to-point in Kent on Sunday.

headline: Lisandro Martinez injury severity confirmed with Man Utd confirming length of absence
body: Argentina centre-back Lisandro Martinez was forced off injured in the second half of Manchester United's win against West Ham on Sunday, with Erik ten Hag worried for the defender
Manchester United defender Lisandro Martinez will not need surgery for the injury sustained against West Ham but could still face two months out.

Argentina defender Martinez returned from injury in January after more than three months out, but went down injured in the second half against West Ham on Sunday. He attempted to play on, but was eventually forced to make way for Raphael Varane.

And United have confirmed the World Cup winner has suffered a sprained collateral ligament. The recovery time for such an injury has been suggested as between one-and-a-half and two months, which would allow the former Ajax man to play again this season.

United will still be able to call upon Varane and the recently returned Harry Maguire in Martinez's absence. Manager Erik ten Hag had suggested the injury was a bad one when speaking after Sunday's victory, with the club now confirming his prognosis.
A statement reads: “Lisandro Martinez has sustained an injury to the medial collateral ligament in his knee and is expected to be out of action for at least eight weeks.

“The Argentine defender left the field in the 71st minute of our 3-0 win over West Ham United at Old Trafford on Sunday. We all wish Licha a speedy recovery and look forward to seeing him back on the pitch later in the season.”
The 26-year-old went down following a challenge with West Ham defender Vladimir Coufal, and Ten Hag's instant response wasn't a positive one.

"Lisandro Martinez's injury does not look good," United's manager said. "It is very bad for him. We wish Licha all the best. It's very bad also for the team. It seems bad. We have to wait and make the right diagnosis. At this moment, we are very sad.

"Hopefully, it is not too bad, but we can only pray. It looks like he has to sit some games out injured again. I can't tell you the details. We have to find out in the next few days what the diagnosis is. He is just returning. He is very important to us. He brings spirit to the team, aside from his football ability."

Ten Hag's side were still able to claim victory despite the loss of their centre-back. Rasmus Hojlund opened the scoring in the first half, extending his current streak to four goals in as many games, while Alejandro Garnacho added two more goals in the second half.

It was a second straight win for United, who had claimed a last-gasp victory at Wolves during the week. The three points lifted them above West Ham, while allowing them to gain revenge for the 2-0 loss at the London Stadium back in December.

United, who didn't make any additions to their senior squad in the January transfer window, travel to Aston Villa next weekend. Villa are coming off a comfortable 5-0 win at Sheffield United, and will be looking to get one over on United after their dramatic Boxing Day defeat.

headline: Rio Ferdinand worries Man Utd's season may just have been 'killed' despite West Ham win
body: Lisandro Martinez limped off in Manchester United's win over West Ham United on Sunday with Rio Ferdinand fearful of what his absence could mean for the remainder of the season
Rio Ferdinand admits Lisandro Martinez's injury could "kill" Manchester United's season.

The Argentine has been out for the majority of the season but his return has coincided with an upturn in form for the Red Devils. Martinez proved to be a hit in his debut term at Old Trafford but without him, the team have struggled to hit the heights expected.

Since Martinez has come back into the fold Erik ten Hag's side have won three on the bounce, scoring 11 goals in the process. But in Sunday's victory over West Ham, the centre-half went down clutching his knee in the second half before coming off in obvious pain.

United have been inconsistent throughout the season and Ferdinand fears that their latest injury blow could be telling. He said on the FIVE podcast: "He got a little injury. He done his knee. I see he tweaked it. I think that looks like ligaments, man. He tried to carry on and then said, 'No, no, no I’ve got to go'.

"So, listen, if he’s out, it kills it. You can see with him and Luke Shaw on that side, when they’re together, they look so dominant, they look so confident, they look so composed with the ball. And those two are really good with the ball in terms of setting up attacks, the ball generally comes from that side."
He added: "So that will be disappointing. We’ve had so many injuries and he’s one of them that’s been out of a while and he’s probably one of our most influential players."

Ten Hag confirmed after the victory that Martinez's injury could prove to be as bad as it looked when he trudged off the Old Trafford pitch. "I can't say but it doesn't look good. There is a bad concern," said the Dutchman. "We have to wait for a few days for the diagnosis. We do everything to get the right diagnosis and see what is the damage.

"He is very sad, very disappointed. We all feel really with him. First of all, it is a personal disaster when it is really bad, but also for the team it is really bad because he definitely brings us a lot."

With Martinez set to be absent, United will have to turn to Harry Maguire, Victor Lindelof, Raphael Varane and Jonny Evans to form partnerships at the heart of defence. There has been a lack of continuity at centre-half this term, owing largely to injury, while several of Ten Hag's options face uncertain futures.

headline: Liverpool snubbed chance to sign Eric Cantona for infamous transfer flop instead
body: Eric Cantona wrote himself into the Manchester United history books through his five years under Sir Alex Ferguson, but he easily could have ended up at Liverpool
Eric Cantona is a Manchester United legend, yet things could have been very different but for the decision of Liverpool manager Graeme Souness.

Cantona arrived in England at Leeds in 1992 following a trial at Sheffield Wednesday and ended up at Old Trafford, where he became a mercurial hero under Sir Alex Ferguson. Those five eventful years at United came after he made a name for himself in his native France – both for his talent and his behaviour.

And it was ultimately the latter of those characteristics which saw Souness decide against taking the risk. The Liverpool boss was offered the chance to sign Cantona, but instead went for what he perceived to be the safer option of Istvan Kozma, who arrived from Dunfermline for £300,000 in February 1992.

Souness has since explained his thinking in rejecting Cantona. "I was manager of Liverpool and we played Auxerre in the cup winners' cup and we lost 2-0 away, we came back and beat them 3-0," Souness explained on The Football Show in 2020. "After the game, Terry Littlewood, who used to look after the players' lounge and my lounge, security-wise, knocked on my door and said there's a pal outside, he's a good friend of yours and he wants to speak to you.

"I said 'who is it?' and he said 'it's Michel Platini'. Not a close pal of mine, the only time I had come in contact with him was when I played against him when I was in Italy. He came in and said 'I've got a player for you, he's a real problem in France but he's really talented and he'd be perfect for your club'. I said 'look, Michel, I'm fighting fires here at the moment, I'm trying to get some people out of the door that are resisting, I'm fighting a dressing room here. The last thing I need is another controversial figure'.

"Eric of course then came over on trial with Sheffield Wednesday, then signed for Leeds and the rest is history. When he went to United, it was a young team and young players need someone like that on the pitch to look up to. I think Eric was certainly one of them."

The story of Cantona at United is well-known – and the fact Kozma’s time at Liverpool is less well documented says a lot about how it went. The Hungary international only played 10 times for the Reds in the end, failing to make an impression at Anfield.

The midfielder made his debut as a second-half substitute in a goalless draw at Ipswich Town in the FA Cup fifth round before a forgettable first start in a 3-0 defeat by Norwich. His first three starts for the club saw Liverpool fail to score a single goal.

His crowning achievement came when he came on as a half-time substitute with the team 3-0 down against Chesterfield in the League Cup. To his credit, Kozma made a difference, setting up goals for Ronny Rosenthal and Mark Wright as Liverpool drew 4-4 in front of a measly crowd at Anfield.

He stuck around for the 1992/93 season, without getting into the team, and was forced to leave at the end of the campaign when his lack of appearances meant he wasn’t granted a work permit. Kozma went back to Hungary to play for Ujpest and had a stint in Cyprus with APOEL before seeing out his career in his homeland.

It wasn’t all bad. Although he didn’t play, Kozma was at Wembley for Liverpool’s FA Cup final win over Sunderland in May 1992 – and it made an impression on him. "It was still the old Wembley and a full house," he recalled in 2021.

"We were sitting behind the bench. The next day we went home to Liverpool, a huge celebration began. First we were taken around the city on an open double decker bus where a lot of scarves were thrown at us. It was a huge experience. I still keep a few of the things."
What do Liverpool need to clinch the title? Keep up with all the Reds news with our FREE daily newsletter

headline: Glazers leave Man Utd fans furious after pressing ahead with Old Trafford controversy
body: The Glazer family have not relinquished their stake in Manchester United despite the club taking investment from Sir Jim Ratcliffe, and the owners have made another controversial decision

Manchester United season ticket holders will be forced to pay more for their seats next season, with reports claiming the measures were put in place before Sir Jim Ratcliffe's stake in the club was confirmed.

Majority owners the Glazer family have been unpopular with sections of the fanbase, some of whom have welcomed the arrival of British billionaire Ratcliffe. However, while future decisions are expected to be made with the input of the new investor, the Old Trafford plans are understood to predate his arrival.

Results have picked up of late for United, who beat West Ham at Old Trafford on Sunday. It followed a dramatic midweek victory away to Wolves, ensuring back-to-back league wins for Erik ten Hag's side for the first time since November.

The relationship between the Glazers and some fans hasn't been the best even when results were altogether more impressive last season, though. Now, a rise of five per cent across the board on season ticket prices are unlikely to improve that situation.

Not only will fans have to pay more next season, a second successive annual increase, but some will be moved to new seats. According to The Mail, those in the Sir Bobby Charlton stand are due to be relocated to accommodate the families of players.

Those in corporate seats will also face higher bills, with some forced to fork out an extra £500 per year. According to communication from United, the changes are designed to ensure the club "operates on a sustainable basis and to support investment in the team and stadium".

United have regularly enjoyed attendances north of 70,000 this season, even with the club struggling in Europe and spending the entire league season outside the Champions League spots. Indeed, Sunday's match against West Ham represented their highest attendance of the campaign at 73,612.

On the field, the late midweek drama at Wolves was followed by an altogether more comfortable win at Old Trafford on Sunday. Rasmus Hojlund opened the scoring, getting among the goals for the fourth straight game, and Alejandro Garnacho struck twice in the second half after West Ham spurned chances to draw level.

Ten Hag insisted he wouldn't be over-celebrating after his team's biggest home win of the season, but pointed to some of the positives. "For today, we are pleased with it, but you need routines to get consistent performances," he said.

"So, you have to make decisions. You have to make decisions in a split second. And when every time you have to swap your team, you have to swap your centre-halves, you have to swap your back four, positioning the right full-back to the left full-back and then swap back again.

"All those adjustments, all those are rules and principles who they know. It's about looking at each other, taking the right decisions. Top football is about details, and when one detail doesn't work, and you concede goals, and then you're following the facts and we had that too much this season."

headline: Marcus Rashford in awkward Man Utd advert promoting alcohol after Belfast bender
body: Marcus Rashford was in Erik ten Hag's bad books last week after a late night drinking session in Belfast with the Manchester United star now featuring in a programme advert promoting alcohol
Marcus Rashford was pictured advertising alcohol in the Manchester United programme - just a week after a late-night drinking session landed him in hot water.

The forward was absent for the FA Cup win over Newport County last Sunday with Erik ten Hag citing an "internal matter". Rashford was pictured in a Belfast nightclub and subsequently missed training the following day, claiming he was ill.

Ten Hag has since revealed he considers the matter closed after speaking with Rashford and his representatives. The England international has copped a huge fine, but that made his appearance in the programme all the more awkward. He posed alongside women's star Mary Earps to advertise Chivas Regal - the whisky brand .

The United boss said on the player's responsibilities: “The players at this level need to manage themselves. That is what you can demand from the player. The player has to know what is good and not good. When you want to play top football, it demands a certain way of life. Always.”

It is not the first time Rashford has found himself in his manager's bad books this season. He headed to a nightclub to celebrate his birthday earlier this season after losing 3-0 in the Manchester derby just hours earlier. Ten Hag claimed his actions were "unacceptable".

Rashford, following a season in which he smashed the 30-goal mark for the first time, is struggling to hit those heights again in a United side that have underwhelmed. His body language on the pitch has been criticised with Rashford previously dipping in and out of form throughout his career.
The 26-year-old provided a positive response when he returned to the team against Wolves on Thursday night, scoring early on in the 4-3 win. He then failed to score as United saw off West Ham.

Gary Neville confessed he was concerned about the conduct of the United forward. He told the Stick to Football podcast: “I’m a little bit worried [about Marcus Rashford ]. I think when someone who's been as peaceful and quiet for the last seven or eight years – almost in some ways perfect for 10 years in terms of his behaviour – and then the last four months, there’s a couple of things that’s happened.

"I always think, ‘Is he alright?’ ‘What’s going on him with him?’ He’s either struggling or he’s thought, ‘I don’t give a f**k’. It’s one of those two things and I don’t think it’s that [the latter], but he’s getting a lot of attention.”

headline: David Moyes says Man Utd 'score was wrong' after miserable Old Trafford return
body: Manchester United cruised to a 3-0 victory over West Ham at Old Trafford on Sunday, continuing Hammers manager David Moyes' poor record away to his former employers
West Ham United manager David Moyes believed his team were better than the 3-0 scoreline suggested in their defeat to Manchester United.

Moyes' team won the reverse fixture back in December but couldn't get on the scoreboard this time around. Rasmus Hojlund put the hosts ahead in the first half, with Alejandro Garnacho adding a brace of his own after the break.

Former United manager Moyes has yet to record an away league win against his old club, though he did lead West Ham to a Carabao Cup victory at Old Trafford in 2021. Sunday's loss was a fourth straight defeat to nil in this fixture in the league, after 1-0 losses in each of the last three seasons.

West Ham had chances to get on the scoresheet, with left-back Emerson spurning arguably the best chance shortly before Garnacho doubled United's lead. Speaking after the game, Moyes made it clear he didn't consider it a 3-0 game.

"No I don't think the scoreline was correct," the Scot told Match of the Day. "Our performance in the main was much better. I am pleased with that but obviously not pleased with different aspects, we didn't finish chances. Overall we played better and our performance was better today."
When asked about Emerson's miss, he said: "That tells you it just was not going to be our day. They broke away and they shoot and it takes a big deflection and that makes it 2-0.

"We have been on a pretty good run without being at our best, with some players also away," he added. "I thought today we looked like it but goals have been a little hard to come by. Hopefully there's a wee bit of mitigating circumstances and hopefully the goals will start flowing in the coming weeks."

West Ham have been without some key players in recent weeks, though they were able to welcome back Nayef Aguerd after the Morocco defender's AFCON exploits. Michail Antonio and Lucas Paqueta are among the high-profile absentees, while the London club allowed Pablo Fornals and Said Benrahma to leave at the end of the transfer window.

There was also an injury scare over goalkeeper Alphonse Areola, but Moyes clarified the Frenchman was withdrawn as a precaution. "It was just a case of we were making sure we were not doing the wrong thing," he said. "He is fine, we just felt there was no point risking him."
The victors have an injury concern of their own, with Lisandro Martinez - only recently back from months out - unable to finish the game. "It seems bad," United boss Erik ten Hag said.

"We have to wait, make the right diagnosis in the coming days and then we will see. Hopefully it is not too bad, we can only pray. He worked so hard to return and now after two games it looks like he has to sit some games out again."

headline: opinionMan Utd trio give touching tribute to Busby Babes in throwback performance vs West Ham
body: Young talent has always been central to the football philosophy at Manchester United, with that ethos and commitment to youth continuing under current boss Erik ten Hag
In the week Manchester United remember the victims of the Munich disaster, it was fitting their young players took centre stage here.

Eight of Sir Matt Busby's Babes died in their prime in the 1958 tragedy, the anniversary of which is on Tuesday, fate decreeing they would never realise their rich potential. Ever since then, young talent has been central to the football philosophy at United, with that ethos and commitment to youth continuing under current boss Erik ten Hag.

On his 21st birthday, Rasmus Hojlund plundered the opener to set United on their way to victory, with 19-year-old Alejandro Garnacho scoring twice after the break to seal the win. And with 18-year-old Kobbie Mainoo continuing to impress with another composed display, the future would appear to be in safe hands at United, despite their inconsistencies this season.

It says everything about United's failings that this was the first home league game this season they have won by more than one goal, victory lifting them up from eighth to sixth place. They may still be eight points off fourth spot, but with 15 games remaining, United have gathered some momentum as they continue to make a late and unlikely push for a Champions League spot.
Despite the scoreline, West Ham produced 22 shots to United's 12, the difference being David Moyes' side were nowhere near as clinical as Ten Hag's men in front of the target.
The first chance went West Ham's way, Lisandro Martinez clattering into the back of Mohammed Kudus outside the United area, but James Ward-Prowse was unable to make the free-kick count.

That missed opportunity proved costly, with United taking the lead moments later in the 24th minute, Casemiro winning the ball deep in the West Ham half. The ball fell into the path of Hojlund, who sent two opponents the wrong way with his quick movement, before burying an unstoppable shot past Alphonse Areola.

Despite going ahead, United were unable to build on it and frustrated their fans with their willingness to sit on their lead and invite West Ham on to them. The visitors created a host of first-half chances but were unable to convert any of them and were dealt a blow when Areola, who had collided with team-mate Kurt Zouma in the first-half, did not emerge for the restart, replaced in goal by Lukasz Fabianski

The Hammers had a chance to level three minutes after the restart, when a lapse in concentration from Harry Maguire allowed Emerson Palmieri to take possession and surge forward. Emerson chose to go it alone, despite options to his right, his decision proving to be the wrong one as he scuffed his shot high and wide.
It proved a significant miss, with United doubling their lead within two minutes, a shot from Garnacho deflecting off Nayef Aguerd, giving Fabianski no chance.
Jarrod Bowen found himself through on goal in the 69th minute, with only Onana to beat, but delayed shooting long enough to allow Diogo Dalot to race back and block his goalbound strike.

United lost Martinez with 20 minutes to go, the defender failing to recover after falling awkwardly minutes earlier when trying to shield the ball from Vladimir Coufal. Any hopes West Ham had of getting back into the game ended six minutes from time, when United counter-attacked, with substitute Scott McTominay setting up Garnacho for his second goal.

headline: Erik ten Hag reacts to "very bad" Lisandro Martinez injury as Man Utd fears realised
body: Argentine defender Lisandro Martinez was forced to make way 20 minutes before the end of Manchester United's 3-0 victory over West Ham at Old Trafford on Sunday
Erik ten Hag confirmed Lisandro Martinez has suffered a "very bad" injury in what is a huge blow for Manchester United.
The Argentine defender was forced to make way 20 minutes before the end of the Red Devils' 3-0 win over West Ham at Old Trafford on Sunday after trying and failing to play through the pain.
The centre-back was caught on the knee by West Ham's Vladimir Coufal and hobbled straight down the tunnel after he made way and was replaced by Raphael Varane.

Ten Hag said: "Lisandro Martinez's injury does not look good. It is very bad for him. We wish Licha all the best. It's very bad also for the team. It seems bad. We have to wait and make the right diagnosis. At this moment, we are very sad."
"Hopefully, it is not too bad, but we can only pray. It looks like he has to sit some games out injured again." He added: "I can't tell you the details.
"We have to find out in the next few days what the diagnosis is. He is just returning. He is very important to us. He brings spirit to the team, aside from his football ability."
Martinez has only recently returned from injury after the defender spent months on the sidelines with a foot problem.
He made his return to the first team against Tottenham in January after missing a staggering 22 games for the Old Trafford club.

headline: Rasmus Hojlund's admission over 'little dressing room group' at Man Utd speaks volumes
body: Rasmus Hojlund opened the scoring as Manchester United comfortably beat West Ham on Sunday, with the Danish striker showing signs that he has finally found his feet at Old Trafford
Rasmus Hojlund appears to have finally settled into life at Manchester United, with the striker admitting he is part of a "little group" in the dressing room.

Hojlund struggled badly in his first six months at Old Trafford following his £72million transfer from Atalanta last summer. It took him until Boxing Day to score his first goal in the Premier League, but that strike has opened the floodgates.

He now scored in the three top-flight games following that win, in the draw with Tottenham, the victory over Wolves and Sunday's triumph over West Ham. The Dane also added United's fourth goal as they knocked Newport out of the FA Cup last week.

Those goals, coupled with the two assists he has also notched in his last four outings, suggest he has found his feet at the Red Devils. And that has further been backed up by the insight the 21-year-old gave into the United dressing room earlier this week.

Hojlund has become close friends with Kobbie Mainoo, who has broken into the United first-team this season. And the Dane has revealed that United's younsgters have formed a group within the dressing room.

“We enjoy spending time together. The young guys have a little group where we're chatting to each other and it's very cool to have other young players around the team. Hopefully we can set an era for the club and be here many years together," he said.

“If you're good enough, you're old enough and I think that's a good thing. We're here for a reason. You can see Kobbie’s composure. He is so relaxed on the ball. Now he's also starting to show that he has the scoring parts of his game as well. He's a complete player.”

That bond between the youngsters was on full display at Old Trafford on Sunday as United comfortably beat West Ham. Hojlund opened the scoring, before academy product Alejandro Garnacho netted twice in the second-half.

To celebrate his first goal, which came thanks to a lucky deflection, Garnacho jumped on the advertising hoardings before crossing his arms. He was joined in the same position by Hojlund and Mainoo, with all three having smiles on their faces.
Hojlund's goal was particularly well taken, as the Dane cut past the West Ham defence before firing in. And the strike was a goal that clearly impressed legendary United captain Roy Keane.

"Obviously United are pressing high up the pitch and they’re getting good bodies up the pitch but Hojlund just scores an absolutely brilliant goal. He’s in form at the moment, this is what the game is about, I love it," he told Sky Sports.

"He feints and the defender thinks he goes onto his weaker side, he cuts back, and he produces these moments - it’s what you want from your top striker. He’s got a lot of confidence, he’s on a good run at the moment, brilliant goal."

headline: Roy Keane proved spot on with "highly unlikely" Man Utd prediction in West Ham win
body: Manchester United led West Ham United narrowly at half-time in their win and Roy Keane correctly predicted that the Red Devils would go on to score more at Old Trafford
Roy Keane was adamant that Manchester United's 1-0 half-time scoreline against West Ham wouldn't remain the same - and was proved right as the Red Devils went on to score two more.

It was their second victory in the space of a few days having also seen off Wolves in midweek. Rasmus Hojlund's impressive strike ensured the hosts went in leading at the interval, although the Hammers showed plenty of promise in the opening 45 minutes.

David Moyes ' side had their chances in the second-half but failed to take them and were made to pay by Alejandro Garnacho, who bagged himself a brace. His first a deflected effort before he finished off a swift break to cap a solid afternoon for United - as Keane predicted.

He said on Sky Sports: "For United, if they sit back in the second half they could find some trouble. What’s been good for them so far, and over the last few weeks, is that their strikers, their attacking players, are in form and are looking good in front of goal.
"They’re doing much better than they were earlier in the season but Man United, they’re still looking quite open so I think it’s highly unlikely that this game finishes 1-0."

Conceding goals has been a problem for the Red Devils, but they've continued to find the net in recent weeks. Scoring four against Wolves and Newport County in the FA Cup with Keane correctly backing their forward options to take their chances.

Hojlund himself, after struggling initially to find the back of the net in the league, has now scored in his last four outings as he continues to find his feet in England. He was bought off late on to a standing ovation as he continues to lead the United line impressively.

Keane said on the Dane: "He’s in form at the moment, this is what the game is about, I love it. He feints and the defender thinks he goes onto his weaker side, he cuts back, and he produces these moments - it’s what you want from your top striker. He’s got a lot of confidence, he’s on a good run at the moment, brilliant goal."

United's comprehensive win was timely as they look to get back into a positive goal difference with their defeats hurting them in that column this term. Their three-goal success now leaves them on minus one and they will look to push on when they face Aston Villa next weekend.

headline: Alejandro Garnacho mocks West Ham star with new celebration in Man Utd win
body: Alejandro Garnacho's first goal saw Manchester United go two goals up against West Ham at Old Trafford and the young winger couldn't help but take a dig at Mohammed Kudus
Alejandro Garnacho could not help but take aim at West Ham's Mohammed Kudus when he celebrated his first goal in Manchester United's comfortable 3-0 win.

The United ace put his side two goals up just four minutes into the second period. Bruno Fernandes found the young winger, who took the ball on the right side of the box before cutting onto his left to fire a shot in.

The strike took a deflection off of Nayef Aguerd on its way past Lukasz Fabianski but that did not dampen Garnacho's celebration. The 18-year-old wheeled away to the advertising hoardings to his right and sat took a seat while placing his hands on his hips.

He was joined by a jubilant Rasmus Hojlund, who opened the scoring against the Irons, and Kobbie Mainoo who both put their arms around their teammate. The trio were all sat comfortable before dropping back down to join the likes of Marcus Rashford in celebration.

It appears Garnacho was providing a firm response as he repeated the celebration after a second goal. He took his place by the Sir Alex Ferguson stand after a cool finish to put his side 3-0 up at Old Trafford.

Kudus produced the celebration when West Ham defeat United in December. The Ghana winger scored the Hammers' second goal on that occasion as David Moyes earned a 2-0 win over his former team after Jarrod Bowen had opened the scoring.
Kudus took his set on the advertising boards in front of West Ham's fans at the London stadium on that occasion and Garnacho could not resist calling back to the moment.

The moment also allowed Garnacho to collect another celebration reminiscent of a Cristiano Ronaldo effort. United's star has been launching into the former Real Madrid star's ‘SIU’ celebration and copied Ronaldo’s ‘sleeping’ celebration by closing his eyes and interlocking his hands over his chest too.

Argentina ace Angel Di Maria has even warned Garnacho to avoid such actions. Speaking to Ole, he said: “The only thing I wouldn’t do is celebrate Cristiano. I would score the goal and I would do like Messi does. I’ll stick with that."

headline: Rasmus Hojlund streak continues in Man Utd win as next gen take centre stage - 5 talking points
body: MANCHESTER UNITED 3-0 WEST HAM UNITED: Rasmus Hojlund kept up his scoring run as he netted the opener to ensure the Red Devils secured successive wins this week with Alejandro Garnacho grabbing a second-half double
Manchester United closed the gap on the top five with a win over West Ham United at Old Trafford.

The Hammers headed to the north west having gone unbeaten in six Premier League games, which included a win over the Red Devils back in December. Six weeks on from that result and United gained revenge with Rasmus Hojlund keeping up his impressive form.

The Dane continues to be in the goals, dropping the shoulder to fire home the opener in what was an underwhelming first-half for the hosts, who were outplayed by the visitors. West Ham were unable to take their chances though and were made to pay by Alejandro Garnacho, who bagged a brace.

His deflected effort put United in total control early in the second-half and the Hammers couldn't find a route back into the game. Jarrod Bowen had their best opportunity, only to be denied before Garnacho put the gloss on the result with a cool finish late on. The three points allowed them to close on Tottenham, whose fifth spot could yet mean Champions League football this term.
These are the talking points from Old Trafford.

United's £72million summer signing was beginning to be mocked as his Premier League goal tally remain at zero on Christmas Day, months into his career at Old Trafford. The raw forward had showcased his quality in Europe and, despite failing to fire in the league, it was always a case of when, rather than if.

Hojlund bagged his first in the Boxing Day win over Aston Villa and the floodgates have since opened with the confidence flowing through him. The Dane's strike against the Hammers was that of a man who had total belief in his own ability.

A number of his attacking colleagues have copped flack for failing to deliver this season, but Hojlund always showed enough to warrant patience and he's more than paying back that faith now, scoring in his last four league outings.

Few things can be more frustrating than seeing your side impose themselves as an away outfit, only to get back on the bus with no points. That will be Moyes this evening with West Ham certainly showing why they've enjoyed such lofty heights this term.

In the opening exchanges they showed ambition and were, for large parts, better than United, but simply couldn't take their opportunities. West Ham went into half-time enjoying the better of every stat, except the one that mattered.

Harry Maguire presented Emerson with a golden opportunity to level early in the second-half, which he blazed over. Within 60 seconds United had doubled their lead thanks to a deflected Garnacho strike, all but killing West Ham's hopes.

Youth has often provided a beacon of hope for those at United, even during the difficult times. Garnacho is among those to show he has the appetite to succeed at one of the world's biggest clubs and his strike made it 2-0 after 49 minutes as he reeled away in celebration.

He was followed by Hojlund and Kobbie Mainoo, the scorer of the winner against Wolves in midweek. The trio posed on the advertising boards with Old Trafford on its feet. They could prove to be three of the most crucial cogs at United for the next decade and beyond as they sat smiling cheek to cheek. Aged just 18, 19 and 21 - the future looks bright with those youngsters firing.

It was all looking so good for the World Cup winner. Say what you want about the Argentine's size, but the bottomline is he's returned from a lengthy injury lay off and helped United win two games in the space of four days - something they've not achieved that often this season. He's slotted straight into the backline, forming a partnership with Maguire, whom he'd have hardly played with last term.

However Martinez landed awkwardly when he was involved in a scuffle as he tried to usher the ball out of play. He went down clutching his knee with team-mates rushing over to check on him. Despite efforts to run it off the centre-half trudged off on 70 minutes with the look of a man who wasn't entirely convinced with the state of his fitness.

Whenever Moyes returns to Old Trafford he must walk past the home dugout and wonder what might've been had he done things differently. As an away manager though he's still awaiting his first win in almost twenty visits.

He was present for some landmark draws, particularly the 4-4 when he was manager of Everton that cost United the title in 2012. Wins though have eluded him with his Hammers side unable to press home a 1-0 advantage last term in the FA Cup. This season he'll have been buoyed by their performance, particularly in the first-half, but remains winless at a visiting manager to the red half of Manchester.

headline: Gary Neville singles out the Man Utd player Erik ten Hag was forced into signing
body: Former Manchester United captain Gary Neville does not believe that the Red Devils would have signed midfielder Sofyan Amrabat had Kobbie Mainoo not had an issue during the summer
Manchester United were forced into signing Sofyan Amrabat in the summer according to Gary Neville.

The midfielder arrived at Old Trafford on transfer deadline day in September as they looked to strengthen Erik ten Hag's hand. The Morocco international joined on an £8.5million loan, with the Red Devils holding an option to make the deal permanent for £21.4m.

The 27-year-old has made 17 United appearances this term and returned to Ten Hag's squad for the clash with Manchester United after a stint at the Africa Cup of Nations. His time away has seen young midfielder Kobbie Mainoo continue his rise to prominence however.

The 18-year-old scored his first goal for the club against Newport in the FA Cup, quickly followed by an impressive Premier League winner against Wolves to earn United three points. Mainoo's reputation is quickly growing and he has established himself as a regular in Ten Hag's midfield while Amrabat has been absent.

Former Man United defender Neville revealed that Mainoo's talent was appreciated much earlier at the club however. The pundit suggested that an injury to the teenager was the only reason United decided to make the move to land Ambrabat from Fiorentina.

He said: "To be fair to Ten Hag, I made the inquiry in the transfer window over the summer about whether they needed another central midfielder. Amrabat was linked with them at the time but they’ve said that if Mainoo hadn’t been injured, they’d have not brought anyone in.

"Because he did go down, Amrabat came in but the faith was there in him from the start. He’s proven already that he’s got the quality as well as the temperament to play in these big matches, he’s a real star."

Mainoo has wasted little time in convincing those less familiar of him with his talent too. Rasmus Hojlund arrived in the summer in a £72m deal and was quickly told about the midfielder that was leaving tongues wagging.

Following Mainoo's match-winning goal in midweek, Hojlund said: "I didn’t get to see him in pre-season because I wasn’t there. But all of the lads were talking about him and saying he is a generational talent. He has a nice body type, he is very mature and has a good personality as well.

"He’s very calm, and outside the pitch he’s a nice, relaxed guy. You can see he’s composed and shows his quality, and he showed it again tonight - he’s an incredible talent. He’s only 18-years-old, and I thought I was young."

headline: Man Utd fans brutally troll Kurt Zouma over cat scandal after Rasmus Hojlund foul
body: Kurt Zouma pleaded guilty to kicking and slapping a cat in 2022 after a gruesome video surfaced on social media, and Manchester United fans aren't letting him forget it
Manchester United fans brutally trolled Kurt Zouma after the West Ham defender was fouled by Rasmus Hojlund during their clash on Sunday.

French centre-back Zouma was filmed physically abusing a cat in 2022 and has had to deal with various taunts from opposition fans since. Hojlund, who'd scored to make it 1-0 to the home side in the 23rd minute, was defending a corner shortly after and poked Zouma in the eye. United supporters in the Stretford End were heard chanting when Zouma was down: "That's how your cat feels!"

The 29-year-old former Chelsea and Stoke defender was sentenced to 180 hours' worth of community service after pleading guilty to kicking and slapping the cat. Zouma regularly takes stick from supporters of other clubs and social media users often enjoy making a dig at him.

One posted during Sunday's match: "Zouma has gone down like a cat being punched in the face by a professional athlete." Another added: "Wonder if the cat he kicked went down as easy as him after a finger in the face."

Zouma expressed his "great remorse" over the much-criticised incent during an interview in 2022, telling West Ham's website: "It's been a difficult spell for me and my family. Obviously I have done something very bad and I apologise again for what I’ve done. I know it was very tough for people to watch and to see that and obviously I feel very, very sorry.

"I have great remorse about it and now I’m trying to move on with my family and looking ahead. I learned from it, that's the most important thing, I would say. Obviously, I had support from many, many people around me who helped me stay focused on football and I try to stay happy.

"The club has been unbelievable with me, the support that I received from my teammates, from the staff, and everyone at the club, and even from the fans, has been unreal, and they helped me stay focused on the game, to try to do my best on the pitch all the time and, obviously, I can’t thank them enough for what they've done. This club is like my family."

His brother, Yoan - who admitted one count of aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring his older brother to commit an offence - was ordered to carry out 140 hours' worth of community service. Having fined the player, West Ham made donations to nine animal welfare charities in the UK and overseas.

headline: Roy Keane and Gary Neville send Man Utd reality check with warning to Erik ten Hag
body: Manchester United returned to winning ways in the Premier League in midweek, beating Wolves in a seven-goal thriller to reignite their hopes of a strong second half of the season
Roy Keane and Gary Neville both believe that finishing fifth is as good as Manchester United can hope for this season.

Kobbie Mainoo's dramatic, injury-time, winner at Wolves kept United in touching distance of the top six after an extremely patchy opening half to the Premier League season. And the memorable 4-3 victory at Molineux has sparked hopes that Erik ten Hag's side could put a run of form together between now and May.

At the start of the campaign there was a thought that United could insert themselves into the title picture, having finished third and reached two cup finals in Ten Hag's maiden season in charge. But after suffering nine defeats in their opening 22 matches, they are already a distant 11 points off the top four, albeit with a game in hand.

Speaking ahead of the clash with West Ham at Old Trafford, the two Red Devils legends both suggested that a top-four spot was all but out of reach. Finishing fifth could be enough for the Champions League this season, and Keane and Neville agree that should be the overall target for the season.
Keane said: "A positive end for them this season would be finishing fifth and getting back into the Champions League if that’d be enough for them to do so.
"I think they have enough, they have one or two important players back which’ll help them balance the squad out but most importantly, they’re scoring goals again.
"They’ve been giving away sloppy goals but the fact that the attacking players are scoring, it helps them because the lack of goals was very surprising to me in the first half of the season."

Neville added: "Roy said it that fifth is the best I think they could ever possibly do. One of those teams, Aston Villa or Tottenham, would have to slip up because I don’t think they’re anywhere near Arsenal, City or Liverpool - those teams are gone."

The arrival of Sir Jim Ratcliffe and Ineos has increased optimism at Old Trafford, with the British billionaire assuming control of the football operation from the much maligned Glazers. And Neville has warned that the new minority owners won't be afraid to dispense with Ten Hag, if they are unable to achieve their aims.
"For United and Erik ten Hag, if he wants to continue here at Man United, he’ll have to impress those above him before the end of the season," the Sky Sports pundit continued.

"INEOS and Sir Jim Ratcliffe, they’ll go into that club and be disruptive, they have to be, so I think that they’re all under pressure. They need to deliver, so much money has been spent on that squad and they’ve underachieved so much this season that it’s incredible."

headline: Erik ten Hag informs Sir Jim Ratcliffe of 'next marquee signing' he wants at Man Utd
body: Manchester United boss Erik ten Hag is looking to land Crystal Palace star Michael Olise in the summer but will face stiff competition from Manchester City for his signature
Manchester United boss Erik ten Hag has made it known that he wants Michael Olise to be his marquee capture in the summer.

He will not enjoy a free run at the Crystal Palace star though with Manchester City ready to rival them. Sir Jim Ratcliffe has recently taken control of the football operations at Old Trafford and his influence over transfer dealings is expected to begin this summer.

The Red Devils' squad is in need of reinforcements and Olise is one of the hottest prospects in the Premier League. He's continued to thrive at Crystal Palace, signing a new deal in the summer as the Eagles warned off interest from Chelsea, who are expected to return again in the summer.

The expectation though, according to The Sun, is that United and City will be the frontrunners. Pep Guardiola's side are ready to throw more than £60million at the winger, who will only move if he is guaranteed game time at the Etihad.

Olise's new deal included a release clause, although that figure is not yet widely known. He's scored six times this term and provided a further three assists in a Palace side that have struggled throughout the season.

Ten Hag is seeking more reinforcements after a hit and miss history in the market as United boss. The team are in need of improvements on the flanks with a host of their options underperforming. Antony, one of the club's most expensive ever signings, has failed to live up to expectations.

Jadon Sancho is likely to depart on a permanent basis in the summer having fallen out with Ten Hag. There is also pressure on Marcus Rashford to consistently produce the form he showed last season with the team continuing to struggle in the final third.

Palace chairman Steve Parish said when Olise opted to sign a new deal back in August: "With Wilfried [Zaha] going, it would have been a blow to lose Michael. We're now going into the season with pretty much the team we ended last season with. We'll try to do one or two more things next week but this makes us all feel a bit better. Michael's got his own mind and people have got to make decisions about their own life.

"We have given him the room to do that and the fans will love him all the more for making that decision. I think Michael will go right to the very top of the game but right now, for his development, this is a good decision."

headline: Jose Mourinho's message to Marouane Fellaini after ex-Man Utd star's retirement - "I don't forget"
body: Marouane Fellaini has called time on his career at the age of 36 with Jose Mourinho hailing the midfielder he worked with for several seasons during their times at Manchester United
Jose Mourinho told Marouane Fellaini he will "never forget you gave me everything" after the Belgian announced his retirement.

The Special One and the midfielder crossed paths at Manchester United, where Mourinho was in charge for two-and-a-half seasons. It was shortly after his sacking that Fellaini moved on, joining Chinese outfit Shandong Taishan, where he'd played ever since.

Now, at the age of 36, Fellaini has opted to call time on a career that also saw him excel for Standard Liege and Everton. He posted the news on Instagram with Mourinho commenting to showcase his admiration.
He said: "I don’t forget who gave me everything he could give. You were and will always be one of mine. Congratulations on your career and rest those ankles that suffered a lot."

Fellaini himself hinted that, whilst his playing days are over, he could still find work in another footballing avenue. He wrote: "As I embark on this new chapter in my life, I look forward to new challenges, but be assured, I will continue to support the beautiful game in any way I can. See you soon!"

The Belgian moved to Manchester in 2013 after David Moyes, who signed him at Everton, opted to do the same when he became United boss. Louis van Gaal succeeded the Scot after his short-lived tenure and found plenty use for the tall Belgian, who won the FA Cup under the Dutch manager.

Fellaini continued to be a regular under Mourinho, making 47 appearance in the Special One's first year as he captured the League Cup and the Europa League. He scored nine goals in his two full seasons under the Portuguese boss.

Mourinho issued plenty of praise to Fellaini throughout their time together, underlining his importance and continued improvements. When he was in charge at Old Trafford he said: “I am very happy with him. He is one of the players that has improved from last season.

”He’s playing well in different positions. You can feel his commitment, his heart and his happiness to be at the club, and to stay at the club, and to play for the club. Clearly, he is showing that famous thing of the team being more important than one of us and he has sacrificed himself for the team.

”He is being more defensive in some matches and then being almost like a striker in others, like he was in the last match [at Old Trafford] when we needed a goal and we had one player less. I’m really happy with Marouane’s stability and performances.”

headline: Mason Greenwood defended by Getafe boss as "great guy" with "exemplary behaviour"
body: Manchester United forward Mason Greenwood has regularly received verbal abuse during his loan spell with Getafe following police charges including attempted rape, which were eventually dropped
Getafe manager Jose Bordalas has described Manchester United loanee Mason Greenwood as "a great guy" who shows "exemplary behaviour."

Greenwood, 22, has been in the headlines this week after England star Jude Bellingham was accused of calling him a 'rapist' after making a crunching tackle on him during Getafe's 2-0 defeat at home to Real Madrid on Thursday. In February 2023, Greenwood had charges of attempted rape, engaging in controlling and coercive behaviour, and assault occasioning actual bodily harm dropped by the Crown Prosecution Service.

An expert lip-reader believes that Bellingham did indeed make the slur at Greenwood, who's also had chants involving the word 'die' aimed towards him this season by various groups of opposition supporters. La Liga have now launched an investigation after Getafe complained and boss Bordalas has defended the forward, who'll remain with the Spanish club until the end of this season.

"I know the same thing that you know," Bordalos told a press conference. "It's not up to me, it's the club, La Liga and the (Spanish Football) Federation (RFEF) that have to make an assessment about it. The only thing that I can say is that I ask for respect for Mason Greenwood because he is a great guy. He is a man who respects everyone and has exemplary behaviour."

After Bellingham's alleged slur had gone viral on social media, Getafe - who are also based in Madrid - asked referee Ricardo de Burgos Bengoetxea to note the allegation in his match report. The 20-year-old, who cost Real £88million to sign from Borussia Dortmund and is expected to be one of England's most important players at the European Championships this summer, could be subject to a disciplinary case led by the RFEF.

Bellingham will next be in action at 8pm on Sunday when Real host rivals Atletico Madrid in their local derby. Getafe will also play on Sunday, as Greenwood and his team-mates travel to face Real Betis. The United academy graduate has scored four goals and provided four assists across 18 La Liga appearances this season, prompting speculation over a big-money transfer move.

Barcelona are reportedly interested alongside Valencia and Real Sociedad. Greenwood's move to Getafe was shrouded in controversy, with United deciding that he'd continue his career away from Old Trafford amid protests from supporters regarding his potential return.

Bordalas and his colleagues "bet on him," though, as the Getafe manager told Marca in December: "Greenwood is a different player, with a lot of talent but in this football talent is not the main thing. It takes more work than talent. We were confident because of the talent, because of the level he has had.

"Being able to opt for a player of this level at Getafe is complicated, almost impossible. And well, given the situation, we bet on him. We are happy and content because we have a great player, he is a good boy, he has fitted in really well and he just needs to learn a little more Spanish."
Manchester United have confirmed how long Lisandro Martinez will be out of action for.

The Argentinian's knee buckled under the weight of a challenge by Vladimir Coufal. While the 26-year-old attempted to continue, he was eventually forced off the pitch to be replaced by Raphael Varane.
After reports in Argentina regarding the severity of the injury, United have confirmed Martinez has suffered medial collateral ligament damage to his knee. He is expected to be out for eight weeks.
Lisandro Martinez has vowed to come back fighting after agonisingly suffering a third long-term injury since his 2022 arrival.

The Argentina World Cup winner has been ruled out for up to two months after sustaining knee ligament damage that forced him off in the second half of Sunday’s 3-0 win over West Ham. The 26-year-old had only returned from foot surgery three weeks ago.
Martinez has played just ten times all season after a recurring metatarsal injury led to a second round of surgery in September.
MEN Sport's latest episode of the Manchester Is Red podcast is now live!
Today we discuss Sunday's 3-0 win over West Ham, Lisandro Martinez's agonising injury setback and Mason Greenwood's future amid his form for loan club Getafe.
You can watch the podcast below.
INEOS are currently weighing up the merits of Ten Hag even if they won't openly admit to it.
Even if form this season has been mixed at best, the emergence of some of the young talent at Old Trafford in recent weeks is pleasing to see.
Hojlund, Garnacho and Mainoo are the future of this team and the United boss should deserve credit for bringing them through and another season at least to see them progress.
One of United's key stars for the future Alejandro Garnacho has expressed his thoughts on his new position for the Reds and how he feels it will benefit the club.
He told MUTV:

We connect very good I think, with me now playing on the right. With Rashy on the left, putting in crosses, and Bruno [Fernandes] in behind. We think we have a good team in the front. I always try to help the team, score and assist, but I don't care if I score or if it's Rasmus or Rashy who scores.
Incredibly, Eintracht Frankfurt have opted to omit United loanee Van de Beek from their Europa Conference League squad.
Van de Beek has yet to complete a full 90 minutes for his new club but he has made three appearances so far this season.
The Dutchman was an unused substitute this weekend during the 2-0 defeat to FC Koln.
If Martinez is out for the next eight weeks, the defender should return on April 1.
In which case, he would miss eight matches in total, seven of which come in the Premier League.
His first match back should be the away trip to Chelsea on April 3.
Carragher's comments about Arsenal players celebrating has gone viral in the past 24 hours but it turns out he was keen to see one player celebrating yesterday.
He told Sky Sports' Monday Night Football:
And you know what, I was pleased for Hojlund.And you see the celebration here...(laughs).
I'm not talking about celebrations again, bu he looks a lot more relaxed.
Now Martinez's injury setback has been confirmed, the next task will be to figure out who will replace him in the starting XI.
The obvious choice would be Varane however the Frenchman has not been preferred by Ten Hag when partnering Maguire.
Lindelof is another option for the Reds and may be selected due to Ten Hag's thoughts on what constitutes a good centre-back pairing.
The Reds have now confirmed the timescale for Martinez's injury.
At eight weeks, the defender is expected to miss several key clashes between now and the end of the season.
United have confirmed Martinez has sustained a medial collateral ligament injury.
It is expected the Argentine will be out of action for at least eight weeks.
Manchester United have had several games selected for live TV broadcast in March, meaning kick-off times have been altered.
And on Saturday, March 30, United will travel to Brentford at 8pm with Sky Sports broadcasting the match live.
Otherwise, United's 3pm kick-off with Sheffield United at Old Trafford on Saturday, March 16 may be moved should the club reach the quarter-finals of the FA Cup.
March 16 - Sheffield United (H) at 3pm
March 30 - Brentford (A) at 8pm on Sky Sports
With the wait for an official line on Martinez's injury prognosis continuing, MEN Sport has put together a handy guide as to what we know about the centre-back's latest setback.
Find out everything that has been said, what the injury is and crucially when he will return here.

At 26, Martinez's time at United could end in unison with Fernandes but after less than two years in Manchester, the Argentinian is already showing leadership qualities which could make him the next captain.
As Keane mentioned, his character is second to none and he drives the standards on the field for the Reds.
It cannot be underestimated just how big a miss he could be in the next few weeks.
Former United captain Keane was singing the praises of Martinez just last month when he returned to the fold at Old Trafford.
The Sky Sports pundit hailed Martinez's 'character' and described him as the 'kind of lad you want to be in the trenches with.'
It has been clear for some time how crucial Martinez is for the back line and his absence will be a worry for Ten Hag.
Our Senior Football Writer Tyrone Marshall writes:

It was probably no coincidence that Manchester United’s best week of the season came when Lisandro Martinez returned to the side. The Argentine gives them so much not just defensively but going forward as well. There have been times this season - this week, even - when United have defended well as a unit, but individually Harry Maguire is having a good season and Raphael Varane has been good since his return to favour. But neither of them brings the calmness on the ball and the quality in possession that Martinez provides. His ability to take the ball under pressure and progress it forward is unparalleled for a centre-back at Old Trafford and what’s more, he does it with his left foot, bringing balance to the backline.
Read more here.
Previously, Ten Hag has been reluctant to play Maguire and Varane together at the back however he did opt to bring the Frenchman on to partner the former captain on Sunday.
Lindelof is also another option but it feels like Varane is the safe pair of hands to come into the back four.
If the reports are true and he is out for the maximum period of two months, Martinez will miss some integral matches.

His return would be earmarked for Liverpool at home. During this time, he would also miss the fifth round of the FA Cup against Bristol City or Nottingham Forest as well as a potential quarter-final should the Reds progress.
The problem for Martinez centres around his knee once again.
United's centre-back has missed much of this season due to problems with this joint.
South American reports claim he has suffered a sprained collateral ligament which could take up to two months to heal.
The defender had just returned from surgery on his knee after tweaking the injury from last season in this campaign.
Martinez will join an injury list which was just starting to decrease at Old Trafford.
According to TyC Sports journalist Gaston Edul, Martinez's injury may not be as bad as feared.
It is believed the worst case scenario of an ACL injury has been ruled out.
However, it is thought the defender suffered a sprained collateral ligament. It is understood a recovery time of one-and-a-half to two months will be needed to recover but no surgery shall be needed.
Following the victory on Sunday, Ten Hag declared Martinez's injury a 'personal disaster' as the centre-back buckled under the weight of opposition defender Vladimir Coufal.
Despite attempting to continue, Martinez was resigned to defeat as he was eventually substituted for Varane.
Good afternoon and thank you for joining us on the United blog.
My name is Jack and I will be taking you through the latest Reds news this afternoon following a brilliant 3-0 victory over West Ham.
Sadly though, the result was marred by an injury to Martinez and we will be focusing on the latest regarding him first.

The OCB supercomputer predicts that the Red Devils will finish sixth in the table, 12 points off the top four.

United won the game 3-0 at Old Trafford with Rasmus Hojlund and Alejandro Garnacho (2) settling the scores in a comprehensive victory.

Manchester United have held talks with two former Premier League managers to replace Erik ten Hag at the end of the season, it is claimed.
Caught Offside claim that Antonio Conte and Julen Lopetegui have been sounded out as potential replacements for the Dutchman in the summer.
Conte has been out of work since leaving Tottenham last year whilst Lopetegui departed Wolves on the eve of the season.
