Man United legend Alan Smith has heaped praise on Red Devils striker Rasmus Højlund.

"I think Højlund is going to get better and better," he said via BritishGambler.co.uk. "It’s difficult for him to lead the line and play as a single striker on his own at the minute, but he will develop into a great number 9 for United.

"Just having a little bit of time will help him. The team obviously hasn’t hit the ground running and it was a difficult period when he came in, but I think he’s starting to get the rewards and scoring the goal has helped him.

"I just feel that he has all the attributes to be a really good centre forward; he’s quick, he holds the ball up well – there’s a lot of positives for him but it hasn’t been easy, because the team hasn’t been playing as well as possible, but there have been sparks where you have seen the quality that he’s got. The more confidence he gets, the better he will become."
If Sir Jim Ratcliffe corrects just one department at Manchester United this forthcoming summer, it has to be the recruitment department.

For far too long, United have been guilty of over-spending on players, courtesy of poor strategic planning and rash decision-making. As part of their minority investment at Old Trafford, INEOS have secured management of the club's football operations, meaning they will oversee all aspects of recruitment.

INEOS, of course, have acted swiftly to try and lay the foundations for a brighter future on that particular front, swooping for Omar Berrada, who has been installed as the club's new CEO, from Manchester City. He has already warned about the dangers of paying over the odds for players - something United have been guilty of time after time.

headline: Manchester United confirm Lisandro Martinez injury and give timeframe for return
body: Lisandro Martinez sustained a knee injury in the 66th minute of Man United's win against West Ham and was forced off five minutes later.
Lisandro Martinez is set for two months on the sidelines after he suffered knee ligament damage in the win against West Ham at Old Trafford.
Martinez's knee buckled under the weight of West Ham defender Vladimir Coufal in the 66th minute of United's 3-0 Premier League win at Old Trafford and he was forced off in the 71st minute.

The 26-year-old had a scan on Monday morning and although he is set for around eight weeks on the sidelines, it revealed he did not require surgery and the injury wasn't as bad as first feared, with the damage to the medial collateral ligament.
United manager Erik ten Hag described the injury as a "personal disaster" for Martinez, who recently returned from nearly four months out with a foot injury.
"He is very sad, very disappointed," Ten Hag said on Sunday. "We all feel really with him. First of all, it's a personal disaster when it's really bad. But let's wait for what it is.
"But for the team, also it is really bad because he definitely brings us a lot."

headline: Manchester United youngsters deserve three signings to start their own era
body: Man United have won three games in a row for only the second time this season and they have the nucleus of a promising side.

You will recognise the photograph but maybe not its name. Sir Alex Ferguson would. Lunch Atop A Skyscraper, the image of 11 workers having a breather on a steel beam 800 feet high in Manhattan during the construction of the Rockefeller Plaza in 1932, adorned Ferguson's office wall when he was the Manchester United manager.
Ferguson's affinity with New York dates back decades (he owns an apartment there) and he noticed the image is of 11 workers. An obvious parallel with the day job.

Apprentices at United would be ushered into Ferguson's office and the Scot would draw their attention to the picture. Cristiano Ronaldo evocatively recalls seeing it and being struck by the absence of a single safety harness.

That image came to mind as Alejandro Garnacho, Rasmus Hojlund and Kobbie Mainoo assembled for United's second goal against West Ham. The only peril they were in was of tumbling a few feet into the terraces but the bond and unity was comparable with the New Yorkers.

"The picture covered a lot, I think, of the three youngsters celebrating together," Erik ten Hag said. "It's not about one player, it's about a team. That's what I have seen today. It looked like a team. 11 defending, 11 attacking. For me, it was enjoyable to watch."
Garnacho mimicked the West Ham winger Mohammed Kudus's celebration and described it as an "inspiration". But the similarity with an image captured almost a century ago is more relevant.

Ten Hag was free to pick his strongest United team in both fixtures last week, they won back-to-back Premier League games for the first time since November and racked up seven goals - more than they had tallied in their previous six league matches. The word "team" surfaced nine times at his post-match debrief.

"I'm not telling you we are there where we want but you see the potential," Ten Hag said. "But you can only work on the potential when the team is available and when certain positions are not available you have to be creative. We have times in the season where every time we have to adapt to put an XI out and now in this moment, we don't have."

Garnacho, Hojlund and Mainoo are at the forefront of United's mini resurgence. That they are so integral is hardly revelatory. Mainoo was preparing to start the season in the starting XI during pre-season until the Real Madrid winger Rodrygo collided with his ankle in Houston in late July.

Mainoo's first-team return came four months later and that was overdue. He had been fit for more than a month but was eased back in, featuring in a Uefa Youth League and EFL Trophy match. His selection at Salford City on Halloween was a disappointment as he should have been with the first team, preparing to face Newcastle in the League Cup 24 hours later.

That tie was a missed opportunity. United were reeling from a 3-0 derby defeat and there was a chance to turn the page in the competition they won last season. Some of Ten Hag's selections were uninspiring (Anthony Martial and Antony) and there was a second successive 3-0 home humbling.

Garnacho, Hojlund and Mainoo were not selected in the same XI until Liverpool away on December 17, when United gained a creditable point. The trio have started in all but one of the past nine games except the defeat at Nottingham Forest as Hojlund was unwell.

Hojlund turned 21 on Sunday but his coming of age moment was the instinctive winning volley against Aston Villa on Boxing Day. He has scored in every league start since and broke double figures against West Ham. Garnacho has claimed two two-goal hauls and Mainoo's name is now in the goalscoring charts.

"Us young guys, we have a little group and we're chatting to each other and it's very cool to have other young players around the team," Hojlund told the Manchester Evening News last week. "And hopefully we can set an era for the club and be here many years together."

"We now have a team that is in balance on the pitch," Ten Hag stressed. "We can play better, also you see the progress is coming. We bought players in the summer for the future, we also made choices to give players who deserve it, to give opportunities in the first team as Garnacho and Mainoo.

"Mainoo in the second game against Madrid gets a real bad injury, then the plans you have, you have to adapt. Hojlund had a period, he came late in, young, but you see he is progressing, when there is a consistent team in his back with routines they will serve him better and you see a frontline in balance.
"It is a threat for every opponent and also you see they enjoy it, to play football, they enjoy it, to give opponents problems, they want to do the togetherness."

There was some levity at Ten Hag's press conference following his sorrowful update on Lisandro Martinez. He laughed that journalists "didn't believe" that United would come good with their regulars back. "Oh, I did!" replied a witty time-served reporter.
Martinez's potentially lengthy lay-off is a colossal setback but there was encouragement to be extracted from Harry Maguire's proactive performance, even if it was blemished by two glaring errors.

United committed more than £50million to sign two goalkeepers in the summer and Andre Onana had a much-needed stable afternoon, reacting impressively to repel the ricochet off Edson Alvarez. Diogo Dalot and Luke Shaw, tied down on new contracts last year, are nearing their peaks of Ten Hag's first season.

Casemiro's performance level has been reminiscent of his influential first season rather than his start to this season since he returned. Marcus Rashford has looked more engaged over the last week than in the first five months of the campaign. Ten Hag referred to a core squad of "15 or 16 players" and Scott McTominay contributed off the bench for the second time in a week to assist Garnacho's clincher.

It is a promising blend of youth and experience. "They (the youngsters) need experienced players, experienced players who've achieved everything to help them, to put them in the right positions, right moment and right attitude," Ten Hag noted.

Ten Hag claimed United "bought players in the summer for the future". That is true of Hojlund but Onana, Mason Mount, Altay Bayindir, Sofyan Amrabat and Jonny Evans had an average age of 27 when they arrived.

A couple of uplifting wins should not alter plans for next season. United still need a new right-back, a centre-back, at least one midfielder and two forwards. Of that quintet of targets, three have to be recruited to enhance the starting XI.
Then United may have an image of 11 workmates worthy of adorning walls.

headline: Lisandro Martinez does something none of his Manchester United teammates do and it's a problem
body: Lisandro Martinez could be set for another spell on the sidelines and Man Utd have already struggled without him this season.

It was probably no coincidence that Manchester United’s best week of the season came when Lisandro Martinez returned to the side. The Argentine gives them so much not just defensively but going forward as well.

United scored 11 goals in three straight wins and although a goal at each of Newport County, Wolves and West Ham came when Martinez was off the pitch, he gives Erik ten Hag’s side something that no other defender can.

There have been times this season - this week, even - when United have defended well as a unit, but individually Harry Maguire is having a good season and Raphael Varane has been good since his return to favour.

But neither of them brings the calmness on the ball and the quality in possession that Martinez provides. His ability to take the ball under pressure and progress it forward is unparalleled for a centre-back at Old Trafford and what’s more, he does it with his left foot, bringing balance to the backline.

Martinez is arguably the best line-breaking passer from defence in the Premier League and his ability to take players out of the game, firing accurate passes into the feet of his midfielders and forwards, has launched many a United attack.

He also helps with the quality of the build-up play and it’s been noticeable that Andre Onana has been more confident playing short passes out with Martinez in the team with him against Wolves and West Ham.

Defensively he adds something as well, as the most aggressive and front-footed defender in the squad. United have had a soft underbelly this season and they still aren’t doing enough to stop teams from creating chances - West Ham had 22 shots on Sunday - but the Argentine is an excellent one-on-one defender and that counts for something when Ten Hag has tried to turn United into a more attacking, more positionally aggressive side this season.

Of all the players whose absences have affected the form and stability of the team this season, Martinez’s has probably been the most telling, so having only had him back for three games, you can understand why Ten Hag labelled a fresh injury setback for the 26-year-old as a “disaster”.

Martinez immediately looked in discomfort when he went down after a tussle with Vladimir Coufal. He is a tough footballer so when he punches the grass while waiting for treatment it is a sign he is struggling.

That should have been the moment caution prevailed and he was withdrawn, but for some reason he was allowed to return to the field of play and then went down for a second time. It’s certainly possible he could have aggravated the injury in that time.
United are now praying the injury isn’t as bad as feared, but Ten Hag cut a pessimistic figure despite his team securing their most comfortable league win of the season at Old Trafford.

"We do everything to get the right diagnosis to see what the damage is,” said Ten Hag. “He is very sad, very disappointed. We all feel really with him. First of all, it's a personal disaster when it's really bad. But let's wait for what it is.
"But for the team, also it is really bad because he definitely brings us a lot."

There can be no arguments with that statement. Martinez has already missed 34 games since last April with a metatarsal injury that he picked up against Sevilla and then aggravated earlier this season.
If he faces another spell on the sidelines it is likely Varane and Maguire will combine again, although Victor Lindelof and Jonny Evans are in reserve.

None of them offer the quality on the ball or the balance that Martinez does, however. When he doesn’t play United’s build-up suffers and they find it harder to progress the ball and harder to create chances.

Maybe signing a player with similar attributes to Martinez will be a priority this summer, but that will be easier to do if United secure the revenue that comes with Champions League football. That is already an uphill task for them, but it will begin to look like scaling a mountain if Martinez is out for any length of time.

headline: Erik ten Hag has discovered a new Manchester United undroppable this season
body: Man United youngster Alejandro Garnacho scored twice against West Ham on Sunday and he's enjoying an excellent season.
Alejandro Garnacho is currently enjoying the best season of his career for Manchester United.
Garnacho was quiet for large parts of the game against West Ham at the weekend, but he exploded into life when it mattered to score two goals in the second half.

West Ham defender Emerson had successfully marked Garnacho out of the game until he fashioned an opening and fired his shot beyond Lukasz Fabianski in the 49th minute. There was a touch of fortune for that goal due to the deflection but the youngster didn't care.
Garnacho's goal was the reward for his endeavour and his second was the icing on the cake in a close-to-perfect afternoon, which saw United move into sixth position in the Premier League.
Lisandro Martinez's knee injury was the only blemish on the performance. Erik ten Hag admitted he was 'concerned' about Martinez after the win and the replays did not bode well.
Almost immediately after making a recovery from an aggravated foot injury, Martinez could face another lengthy period on the sidelines and a fresh lay-off would be a huge blow.
Martinez is one of the first names on the team sheet when he's fit, but on a positive note, other players in the squad have also staked a claim for that status this season.
Garnacho is one of those who has seemingly become undroppable. He has started the last 19 games and his output in the final third has improved markedly in this campaign.
The winger did not start in the 3-0 defeat to Manchester City at Old Trafford in October but he's started every game since then, recently making a switch to the right side of the attack.
Garnacho, a natural left winger, had no previous experience playing on the right when he started against Aston Villa during the festive period. He scored twice and hasn't looked back.
The 19-year-old was recently asked on a gaming stream which position he preferred - the left or right wing - and he intelligently responded: "Being on the pitch."
There was always a suspicion Garnacho would be just as effective on the right and he's matured in front of fans' eyes this season, adapting to what his manager wants and contributing goals.
Garnacho did not have his best game against West Ham and still scored twice. The ability to score when having a quiet afternoon is invaluable and he now has seven in all competitions.
In comparison, he scored just six goals last season and he could double that haul by the end of 2023/24, which has seen Garnacho finally establish himself as a reliable senior player.
The biggest area of improvement for Garnacho was to start having the same impact when he started games as when he came off the bench and he's certainly achieved that.
Garnacho, Rasmus Hojlund and Kobbie Mainoo perched themselves on the advertising hoarding after United's second goal and the outcome of that celebration was a brilliant photo.

Garnacho is sat in the centre of the trio, with a wide grin on his face. "We bought players in the summer for the future, we also made choices to give players who deserve it, to give opportunities in the first team as Garnacho and Mainoo," Ten Hag said at his press conference.
"Mainoo in the second game against Madrid gets a real bad injury. Then the plans you have, you have to adapt. Hojlund had a period, he came late in, young, but you see he is progressing.

"When there is a consistent team in his back with routines, they will serve him better and you see a frontline in balance. It is a threat for every opponent and also you see they enjoy it, to play football, they enjoy it, to give opponents problems, they want to do the togetherness.

"The picture covered a lot, I think, of the three youngsters celebrating together. It's not about one player, it's about a team. That's what I have seen today. It looked like a team. 11 defending, 11 attacking. For me, it was enjoyable to watch.

"That was our plan before the season because we saw the potential from those players. They need games, they need experience and the only way you get this is to play in the first team, to get the opposition, then adapt and have the right attitude and they keep doing this in togetherness and the attitude to improve every day. Then I am convinced they can achieve very high levels."
Garnacho is reaching 'high levels' this season and his smile isn't going away anytime soon.

headline: Manchester United star Lisandro Martinez breaks silence on fresh injury blow
body: The Man United defender had not long returned from a lengthy setback but now faces more time on the sidelines.
Manchester United defender Lisandro Martinez has vowed to come back fighting after agonisingly suffering a third long-term injury since his 2022 arrival.

The Argentina World Cup winner has been ruled out for up to two months after sustaining knee ligament damage that forced him off in the second half of Sunday’s 3-0 win over West Ham. The 26-year-old had only returned from foot surgery three weeks ago.

Martinez has played just ten times all season after a recurring metatarsal injury led to a second round of surgery in September. The centre-back had initially picked up the problem back in April, a setback that ended his season early.

Erik ten Hag has described the fresh injury as a “personal disaster” for the player with the club confirming the extent of his issue on Monday afternoon. Martinez himself has thanked fans for the well wishes sent his way and is determined to do everything he can to get back fit.

Taking to Instagram, Martinez wrote: “I want to give a heartfelt thanks for the great support I’ve received and to reassure you that I’ll soon be back out there, and we’ll fight together. Always united!”
Martinez is arguably United’s primary centre-back selection. Harry Maguire has generally been in good form while Jonny Evans has more than justified his shock return, but both are north of 30.

Martinez is seen as a long-term figure in the United set-up, yet will not have enjoyed consistent game time for a whole year by the time he recovers from his latest issue. Meanwhile, United are expected to dip into the market for a new defender this summer.

Raphael Varane is set to leave the club upon the expiry of his contract in June with the player unsure whether he would agree to a reduced-terms deal given he feels like he is being pushed out of the club.

Victor Lindelof, who has had his year-long extension triggered, and 19-year-old December debutant Willy Kambwala are the other natural centre-back options while left-back Luke Shaw also has the ability to play at centre-half.

headline: Manchester United could spring Lisandro Martinez replacement surprise after Erik ten Hag comments
body: Manchester United are heading into a crucial period of the season without their first-choice centre-back and the battle to replace Lisandro Martinez has begun
After two weeks of respite, Manchester United find themselves in the same difficult situation they were confronted with for the majority of 2023.

Lisandro Martinez's knee injury is a big loss for the Reds considering what he has brought to the team in just four matches back. The Argentinian's medial collateral ligament damage shall keep him sidelined for the next eight weeks and in that time he will miss a Manchester derby, an FA Cup fifth-round tie and a big trip to Aston Villa among other fixtures.
As the Reds attempt to save their season, Erik ten Hag must battle with the idea of who replaces Martinez. For supporters, this is an easy decision to make.

Raphael Varane has proven, when fit, how good a defender he is and on paper he seems the perfect option to line up next to Harry Maguire who excelled againt West Ham. However, the Dutchman has already explained why he is likely to overlook the Frenchman when it comes to replacing Martinez.

Back in November, he explained: "There are moments in certain games where they [Maguire and Varane] can play together and they have already proven they can do it. But the buildup is not that fluid when one of them is playing from the left centre-back position because I think Licha [Lisandro Martínez], obviously, Luke Shaw, obviously, Jonny Evans and Victor Lindelof, they are right-footed, but they can play really comfortably with their left and make the right angles, then you can construct a better formation where you can start to play."
Due to this belief by ten Hag, he is unlikely to pair Maguire and Varane together from the off. So the question is, who misses out?

Based on his performance against the Iron, Maguire is likely to get the nod at Villa Park meaning Varane will remain on the bench. Such a decision will prove unpopular but moving Shaw centrally or recalling Lindelof to the starting XI seems more plausible at this stage.
Maguire's renaissance under Ten Hag is nothing more than exceptional and he deserves his place in the team. It also serves to underline why Varane's future is now in doubt.

headline: ‘Played a blinder’ - Erik ten Hag earns praise for Man United discipline after Rashford incident
body: Erik ten Hag has been praised for his handling of the Marcus Rashford situation as Manchester United enjoyed a second successive win
Micah Richards has praised Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag for his handling of Marcus Rashford's discipline.

United cruised to three points on Sunday to move to within six points of Tottenham Hotspur in fifth. Alejandro Garnacho scored twice, with Rasmus Hojlund also on target, in a 3-0 win over West Ham United.

It extended their run to three matches without defeat after back-to-back wins, as well as their draw with Spurs. Kobbie Mainoo was the hero in midweek as he scored a stoppage-time winner in their enthralling 4-3 win over Wolves at Molineux.

Richards heaped praise on the former Ajax manager and said the 54-year-old deserves credit for his work on and off the pitch. He told the Rest is Football podcast: "I think (Erik) ten Hag deserves a lot of credit.

"It’s not even just the football side, he put a marker down with the (Marcus) Rashford thing and he could have drawn it out a little bit - obviously he didn’t play in the game against Newport but then he put him straight in. Once you score, all is forgotten about and I think he’s played a blinder.
"Sometimes you are worried with how it is going to go, but I think he needs credit for that because they have needed him, and the team looks a lot better with him in the side."
Ten Hag has endured a difficult season so far, facing pressure following their midseason blip, but has seemingly turned around their fortunes.

Prior to the hectic schedule, United were in the spotlight after Marcus Rashford missed their win over Newport County in the FA Cup and did not train with the squad due to illness after a trip to Belfast.

The 26-year-old returned to face Wolves in the West Midlands where he opened the scoring. Ten Hag described it as an 'internal matter, and in a statement, United said: “Marcus has taken responsibility for his actions. This has been dealt with as an internal disciplinary matter, which is now closed.”

headline: How many Manchester United games Lisandro Martinez could miss after injury blow
body: Manchester United defender Lisandro Martinez is looking at a spell on the sidelines after suffering a knee injury against West Ham United.
Lisandro Martinez could miss as many as nine matches for Manchester United after he was forced off with a knee injury against West Ham United on Sunday.

The Argentine was starting only his fourth match since returning from a previous lengthy lay-off but was forced out of the 3-0 win at Old Trafford after clashing with Hammers defender Vladimir Coufal in the 71st minute. Martinez could be seen clutching his knee in agony after the incident, raising fears that he could be set to endure another spell out of the team.

And that seems to have been confirmed by Argentine journalist Gaston Edul who has shared an update on the situation via social media. As translated, the TyC Sports reporter wrote on X (formerly Twitter): "Lisandro Martinez has a sprained collateral ligament. The worst scenario was ruled out. It is between a month and a half and two months of recovery. You don't have to have surgery. Good news."

The suggestion that Martinez will not require surgery should mean his season has not ended in February, but the 26-year-old is set to miss a number of key matches. Should he need the full two months to recover he will miss eight Premier League games and at least one FA Cup fixture.

Martinez will miss out on the crunch trip to Aston Villa on February 11, where United will attempt to make up some points on the team that currently occupies the fourth Champions League qualification spot. He will also have to sit out a trip to Luton Town on February 18.

A game against Fulham on February 24 is the first home game he will miss. United will face either Bristol City or Nottingham Forest in the FA Cup fifth round on February 28, but they will have to make the midweek trip without their Argentine defender. Of course if United make it through to the quarter-final of the FA Cup, he could miss that too.
Martinez is likely to be more frustrated by the fact that he will be unavailable to face champions Manchester City at the Etihad Stadium on Match 3, before United play host to Everton on March 9.

Another home game against Sheffield United follows on Match 16 before a tricky away trip at Brentford could be encountered without Martinez on March 30. Should he require the full two months out, the final match he will miss is a key trip to Chelsea under the lights on April 3.

Assuming Martinez will be fit again after this date, his first match back could hardly be more significant. United will host arch rivals Liverpool at Old Trafford on April 6, where the opportunity to dent Jurgen Klopp's Premier League title ambitions should serve as motivation alone to get back to full fitness.
February 11 - Aston Villa (a)
February 18 - Luton Town (a)
February 24 - Fulham (h)
February 28 - FA Cup fifth round (TBC)
March 3 - Manchester City (a)
March 9 - Everton (h)
March 16 - Sheffield United (h) or FA Cup quarter-final
March 30 - Brentford (a)
April 3 - Chelsea (a)

headline: Erik ten Hag explains Manchester United players' celebratory picture
body: Man United have won their last three games and scored 11 goals with their youngest starters at the forefront of their form.
Erik ten Hag believes Manchester United are starting to fulfil their potential with a fuller squad available.
United have won all three games since a 13-day winter break, scoring 11 goals against Newport County, Wolves and West Ham.

Rasmus Hojlund has been on target in all three triumphs, Alejandro Garnacho took his tally for the season to seven against West Ham while Kobbie Mainoo netted his first two goals for the club at Newport and Wolves.

The three youngsters came together for a celebratory pose to mark Garnacho's first goal in the 3-0 defeat of West Ham, sitting together on the Old Trafford advertising hoarding. Garnacho mimicked West Ham winger Mohammed Kudus's celebration and described it as an "inspiration".

Garnacho has started the past 18 games while Mainoo has lined up in 11 of the last 15 games since he returned from injury. The midfielder suffered an ankle injury in United's second pre-season tour match against Real Madrid in July that sidelined Mainoo for four months.
"I have to analyse, clinical, calm," Ten Hag explained of United's mini resurgence. "So we now have a team that is in balance on the pitch. We can play better, also you see the progress is coming.
"We bought players in the summer for the future, we also made choices to give players who deserve it, to give opportunities in the first team as Garnacho and Mainoo.
"Mainoo in the second game against Madrid gets a real bad injury. Then the plans you have, you have to adapt. Hojlund had a period, he came late in, young, but you see he is progressing.

"When there is a consistent team in his back with routines, they will serve him better and you see a frontline in balance. It is a threat for every opponent and also you see they enjoy it, to play football, they enjoy it, to give opponents problems, they want to do the togetherness.

"The picture covered a lot, I think, of the three youngsters celebrating together. It's not about one player, it's about a team. That's what I have seen today. It looked like a team. 11 defending, 11 attacking. For me, it was enjoyable to watch.

"That was our plan before the season because we saw the potential from those players. They need games, they need experience and the only way you get this is to play in the first team, to get the opposition, then adapt and have the right attitude and they keep doing this in togetherness and the attitude to improve every day. Then I am convinced they can achieve very high levels.
"But they need experienced players, who've achieved everything to help them, to put them in the right positions. Right moment and right attitude."

headline: Everything we know about Lisandro Martinez injury as Manchester United release statement
body: Lisandro Martinez picked up a nasty-looking knee injury during the 3-0 win over West Ham and Man United have since released a statement

Manchester United have confirmed the injury suffered to Lisandro Martinez picked up during the 3-0 win against West Ham on Sunday afternoon will keep him out for up to eight weeks. Rasmus Hojlund and Alejandro Garnacho (2) were on target in that game as United made it back-to-back victories in the Premier League.

However, three points did not come without a potential cost. Martinez, who has only just returned to the starting XI following a long-term foot complaint, went down clutching his knee at Old Trafford and the Argentine then had to be replaced by Raphael Varane at centre-back for the final 20 minutes.
Following the statement being released by Manchester United, here, we recap what we know about the injury, and what has been said about the player by manager Erik ten Hag;
Martinez went down clutching his (right) knee at Old Trafford on Sunday afternoon and could play no further part after he received treatment on the pitch. The extent of the damage is not yet known.

Reports from Argentina - via Gaston Edul and TyC Sports - state Martinez has "sprained a collateral ligament in his leg" and does not require surgery to correct the problem. Has has been under the knife already this campaign in an attempt to tackle a long-standing foot injury he picked up some time ago.

On Monday evening, Manchester United released a statement on the injury suffered by Martinez with his return timeline and exact muscular issue being revealed. The statement read: "Lisandro Martinez has sustained an injury to the medial collateral ligament in his knee and is expected to be out of action for at least eight weeks.

"The Argentine defender left the field in the 71st minute of our 3-0 win over West Ham United at Old Trafford on Sunday. We all wish Licha a speedy recovery and look forward to seeing him back on the pitch later in the season."
As Manchester United revealed, Martinez is expected to miss up to eight weeks due to the damage to his knee.

Describing the injury as "very bad" at his post-match press conference, Ten Hag chatted at length about his player, but indicated that it was too early to know exactly what he had done. The manager said: "I can't say, it doesn't look good so there's a big concern, but we have to wait for the coming days what the diagnosis is.
"Then we can tell you more. We do everything to get the right diagnosis to see what the damage is.
"He's very sad, very disappointed. We all really feel with him.
"First of all, it's a personal disaster when it's really bad, but let's wait for what it is. But for the team, also, this news is really bad because he definitely brings us a lot."
United continue to sweat on Martinez in the aftermath of the victory. However, there has been one development via teammate Diogo Dalot, who posted a message to the Argentine on social media.
It read: "Your pain is our pain. You will be back soon my brother." Dalot shared that on his Instagram story.

headline: Manchester United player ratings as Rasmus Hojlund and Lisandro Martinez very good vs West Ham
body: Man United beat West Ham in the Premier League at Old Trafford and here are how Erik ten Hag's players rated.
Manchester United leapfrogged West Ham United and jumped into the Premier League's top six with a 3-0 win over David Moyes' side on Sunday afternoon.
United went in front when Rasmus Hojlund scored for the fourth game in a row with a fine first-half finish. Alejandro Garnacho added a second early in the second period when he cut inside to score.

The winger sealed the points in the closing stages with his second of the afternoon and United's third. The only downside for Erik ten Hag was an injury to Lisandro Martinez with the defender forced off in the final quarter.
Andre Onana: Made a good early save from Edson Alvarez's ricochet and dealt dependably with other attempts on target. 7
Diogo Dalot: Pitted against Mohammed Kudus, who switched flanks, and fared well in a tight duel. Brilliantly covered for Harry Maguire's mistake to deny Jarrod Bowen. 8
Harry Maguire: Back in the starting XI for the first time in almost two months and produced one of his strongest performances of the season until he let Emerson Palmieri in. Did likewise for Bowen. 6
Lisandro Martinez: Different partner but same Martinez. Often the defender in the way of a pass or a shot. Had to come off after his knee buckled under the weight of Vladimir Coufal. 8
Luke Shaw: Not as probing in the final third as he has been of late but defensively excellent again before and after Kudus switched to the right flank. 7
Casemiro: Not as influential as in midweek but his pressing led to the opening goal and he shielded United vigilantly as they defended their 2-0 advantage. 7
Kobbie Mainoo: Another tidy performance in front of England assistant manager Steve Holland. Earned a standing ovation and congratulations from teammates when he came off. 7
Alejandro Garnacho: Pocketed by Emerson Palmieri in the first half but wriggled out of it to score early in the second, via a deflection. Then scored again to kill the game. 8
Bruno Fernandes: Drew a vigilant stop from Alphonse Areola and played the ball to Garnacho for the second goal. Could have scored himself but for an errant touch. 7
Marcus Rashford: Embarked on bright bursts with and without the ball and had some shooting opportunities but not on target today. 6
Rasmus Hojlund: Broke double figures in the goalscoring form with his best goal yet for United. Now has four goals in his last four Premier League games. 9
Subs
Scott McTominay: Assisted Garnacho. 7
Raphael Varane: Helped United keep a clean sheet. 7
Victor Lindelof: First game in two months. 6
Antony: Late cameo. 6
Manager
Made one change to rest Varane and United kept a clean sheet, despite West Ham's proactive play. Another good day in the dugout. 8

headline: David Beckham booed after Lionel Messi injury causes international incident in Hong Kong
body: Lionel Messi was left on the bench as his Inter Miami side beat a Hong Kong XI 4-1 in a pre-season friendly, with angry fans chanting for a refund and booing co-owner David Beckham

Manchester United legend David Beckham was met with boos and demands for refunds from fans after Lionel Messi didn't play in a pre-season friendly in Hong Kong. Messi, who's been nursing a hamstring injury, watched from the sidelines as his Inter Miami team beat a Hong Kong XI 4-1.

Videos on social media showed fans chanting "refund" and booing during Beckham's post-match speech. The Hong Kong government expressed their disappointment and warned that match organisers Tatler Asia could face cuts in funding.
Former United midfielder Beckham is co-owner of Inter Miami. He was responsible for bringing Messi to the MLS.
READ MORE:Ryan Giggs digs out Antony and names United player who gives '10 times more'

In a statement, the government said: "The Government today expressed deep disappointment over Messi not playing at Tatler XFEST Hong Kong, Hong Kong Team vs Inter Miami CF, and the organiser failing to provide a detailed explanation promptly.
"The event has been awarded "M" Mark status, as well as a matching grant of 15 million [Hong Kong dollars; £1.5m] and a grant for venue of 1 million by The Major Sports Events Committee (MSEC).

"The Government has also provided a variety of coordination and assistance, including venue arrangement and crowd management, in order to offer football fans a wonderful game and an opportunity to witness the world-class player showcasing his skills."

They added: "Many Hong Kong fans looked forward to the match with enthusiasm, and a lot of tourists came to Hong Kong particularly for the match. The Government, as well as all football fans, are extremely disappointed that Messi could neither play in the friendly match, nor explain to the fans in person upon request

"The way that the organiser and Inter Miami CF handled the situation could not meet the expectations of the fans who showed strong support to Messi, especially those visitors who came all the way here for the match.

"The Culture, Sports and Tourism Bureau and the MSEC will rely on the terms and conditions of the agreement in requiring the organiser to take responsibility, including a reduction of the amount of funding as a result of Messi being not able to play in the match."

headline: Diogo Dalot hints at severity of Lisandro Martinez injury amid Manchester United concern
body: Manchester United's 3-0 win over West Ham United was tarnished by a potentially serious knee injury for Lisandro Martinez
Manchester United defender Diogo Dalot has sent a heartfelt message to Lisandro Martinez after the Argentine suffered another injury concern.

Martinez was forced off shortly after the hour mark after his knee buckled following a challenge from West Ham United defender Vladimir Coufal. It sparks another injury concern for Erik ten Hag after the former Ajax man endured a four-month layoff after sustaining a foot injury against Tottenham Hotspur.

The incident soured a complete United performance as they brushed aside the East London club. Alejandro Garnacho was the pick of the bunch with a brace as Rasmus Hojlund topped his 21st birthday celebrations with a goal.

Images show Martinez in agony after being left in a heap following the Czech Republic international's challenge. And Dalot was among the players to express support amid the anxious wait for the 26-year-old's diagnosis.

"Your pain is our pain. You will be back soon my brother," he wrote in an Instagram story post. Speaking after the triumph, the United boss offered a bleak outlook surrounding the severity of the issue.
"I can't say, it doesn't look good so there's a big concern, but we have to wait for the coming days what the diagnosis is then we can tell you more," he said.

"We do everything to get the right diagnosis to see what the damage is. He is very sad, very disappointed. We all feel really with him. First of all, it's a personal disaster when it's really bad. But let's wait for what it is.
"But for the team, also it is really bad because he definitely brings us a lot."

headline: Manchester United are doing what Rasmus Hojlund said they would after win vs West Ham
body: Wreaths were placed on the Old Trafford pitch in memory of the victims of the Munich air disaster ahead of the 66th anniversary. The latest batch of captivating Manchester United fledglings are starting to spread their wings.

Rasmus Hojlund only spoke of his hope he and his fellow rookies "can set an era for the club and be here many years together" on Thursday night. Here three of them were, sat together, posing in victory.

Alejandro Garnacho mimicked West Ham winger Mohammed Kudus's signature celebration by sitting on the advertising hoarding and facing the pitch. He was joined by Hojlund and Kobbie Mainoo. United fans will hope to be watching and talking about their generation for several years.
United-bred duo Garnacho and Mainoo are still in their teens but Hojlund turned 21 today. His goal on Boxing Day feels like a coming of age and he now has four in his past four Premier League starts.

Mainoo, substituted for the first time since December, earned a standing ovation and compliments from Luke Shaw and Marcus Rashford on his way to the touchline. Erik ten Hag offered a congratulatory pat on the head.

Garnacho gained a chant days after his United debut as a 17-year-old on the night of the FA Youth Cup triumph in 2022. As the frontman, Hojlund deserves a backing band and the Stockport-born Mainoo can expect to enter United's tome of a songbook soon.

The youth were underpinned by the veterans. Casemiro's urgent press made Hojlund's goal possible and, bar one major lapse, Harry Maguire was commanding on his return to the starting XI for the first time in nearly eight weeks.

Maguire relinquished the captain's armband six months ago but is still an authoritative figure. The applause for one interception had barely subsided and he was ushering Lisandro Martinez further forward, acknowledging his superior distribution in the middle third.

When Maguire erred and let Jarrod Bowen in, Diogo Dalot rushed across to hurl his body in the way of the ball, a goal-saving block that brought United fans to their feet. The ball was still live when Maguire thanked him. Dalot has firmly cemented his status as starting right-back and, not for the first time, it has coincided with Aaron Wan-Bissaka going AWOL.

United fans' chants of 'Argentina' began at the Boleyn Ground in support of David Beckham back in August 1998 and one of the loudest renditions came in response to Martinez's tangle with Vladimir Coufal. Martinez's enforced withdrawal was the only negative. Ten Hag admitted it was a "personal disaster".

After squandering two-goal leads at Newport and Wolverhampton, there was an elusive third goal that ensured a rare day devoid of drama. United went 3-0 up for only the third time this term. The last time it happened in a home league fixture was last May.

Ten Hag and one of his predecessors, David Moyes, carried the wreaths when both teams emerged from the tunnel. A besuited Moyes, with the Manchester coat of arms stitched onto his blazer, visited the Manchesterplatz site in Munich when he was United manager in 2014. Supporters present appreciated that.

In West Ham colours, Moyes looked understandably disappointed by their profligacy in the first half and it continued early into the second. Emerson Palmieri seized on Maguire's hesitancy and looked to pass when he had to shoot. He only threatened those in the Scoreboard End. A minute later, Garnacho wriggled out of Palmieri's pocket and scored.

There were high fives and hugs all round for Hojlund, as well as a chest bump from Maguire to mark his 23rd-minute opener. Hojlund has now broken double figures for United goals and his 10th was his most singular. The Dane has scored some great goals and his potential to be a great goalscorer is more apparent with every game.

Hojlund had the confidence to deceive the West Ham defenders and switch the ball to his weaker right foot. He wellied the ball in as though it was his strongest. Whilst players joined the throng, Ten Hag had stuffed his hands back into his pockets. He is nearing vindication with the £72million striker.

Steve Holland, Gareth Southgate's assistant, was in the directors' box and nattering with the United football director John Murtough before kick-off. Five England internationals started across both sides but the one Holland had to have cast his eye over carefully was Mainoo. The 18-year-old drew applause in the 21st minute for a smart shimmy that deceived Kudus before setting Garnacho on his way.

Another England midfielder, Kalvin Phillips, was promptly dropped by Moyes after a chastening debut against Bournemouth in midweek. Phillips's substitute status did not spare the former Leeds and Manchester City midfielder from the Stretford End giving him grief during an early warm-up. Phillips was a good enough sport to engage in the repartee. Then he was robbed of the ball for Garnacho's second goal.
Phillips was still seated when Garnacho, Hojlund and Mainoo sat down.

headline: Erik ten Hag gets brutal warning as Sir Jim Ratcliffe plans sweeping Manchester United changes
body: Investment from INEOS founder Sir Jim Ratcliffe has been formalised - subject to Premier League ratification - and changes have been made behind the scenes

Gary Neville reckons Erik ten Hag might need to usurp Aston Villa or Tottenham in order to keep his job. Change is on the horizon for Manchester United behind the scenes with investment from Sir Jim Ratcliffe rubber-stamped on Christmas Eve - although that deal remains subject to Premier League ratification.

There has been precious little to celebrate at Old Trafford and beyond on the pitch this season. However, now the injury woes have started to subside, United have won their last two matches to move up to sixth-place with goals from Rasmus Hojlund and Alejandro Garnacho (2) doing the damage against West Ham.

Five teams from England - rather than the usual four - could be awarded Champions League spots next campaign and that opens the door up for improved United moving forward. However, with Villa and Tottenham four and six points above them respectively, there is work to do.

Speaking about Ten Hag and his position, Neville told Sky Sports: "That's the biggest decision the new ownership will have to make in the next few months. They'll bring in a sporting director, because there's not one already, but whether they keep the manager is the one everyone will be looking out for come the end of the season."

Neville added: "Roy [Keane] said it that fifth is the best I think they could possibly do. One of those teams, Aston Villa or Tottenham, would have to slip up because I don't think they're anywhere near Arsenal, City and Liverpool.

"Those teams are gone. For United and Ten Hag - if he wants to continue here - he'll have to impress those above him before the end of the season. INEOS and Sir Jim Ratcliffe, they'll go into that club and be disruptive, they have to be, so I think that they're all under pressure.
"They need to deliver, so much money has been spent on that squad. They've underachieved so much this season that it's incredible."

headline: Manchester United might have to try and sell at least 11 players this summer
body: Man United need to clear the decks in the 2024 summer transfer window and begin the process of trying to avoid mistakes of yesteryear.
If Sir Jim Ratcliffe corrects just one department at Manchester United this forthcoming summer, it has to be the recruitment department.

For far too long, United have been guilty of over-spending on players, courtesy of poor strategic planning and rash decision-making. As part of their minority investment at Old Trafford, INEOS have secured management of the club's football operations, meaning they will oversee all aspects of recruitment.

INEOS, of course, have acted swiftly to try and lay the foundations for a brighter future on that particular front, swooping for Omar Berrada, who has been installed as the club's new CEO, from Manchester City. He has already warned about the dangers of paying over the odds for players - something United have been guilty of time after time.

The £85.5million acquisition of Antony from Ajax in September 2022 is a prime example. The art of perfecting recruitment is a two-way system and United have not mastered it in recent years. They have been guilty of stock-piling players, often allowing them to run down their contracts and leave for free, or selling them for minimal fees when the likes of Liverpool and Manchester City have commanded respectable fees for their unwanted stars.

Though they have played their part for United this season, the club's failure to offload both Harry Maguire and Scott McTominay last summer are prime examples of their failure to trim the squad and command hefty transfer fees. United cannot afford to repeat such errors ahead of 2024/25, and it is unlikely that INEOS will allow them to.
This forthcoming summer's transfer window promises to be one of the most intriguing United have faced in years. The eyes of the world will be on Old Trafford to see what impact INEOS have.

If they are serious about taking United back to the top, they need to significantly improve the club's ability to trade in the transfer market. Looking ahead to the summer, the Reds have a whole host of players on their books who need moving on permanently.

Focusing primarily on those who will be under contract at the beginning of next season, you can argue that a minimum of 11 players need selling, both for the benefit of the club and each individual's career. Aaron Wan-Bissaka and Victor Lindelof have both had their contracts extended until June 2025, meaning United have avoided the risk of losing them for free this summer.

United plan to recruit a first-choice right-back ahead of next season, meaning either Diogo Dalot or Wan-Bissaka will need moving on. Dalot has a higher ceiling, meaning it would make sense to cash in on Wan-Bissaka this summer, with the next transfer window representing United's last chance to try and secure a respectable fee for him.
The same can be said for Lindelof. United want to sign a new centre-back this summer, meaning the Swede's game time could be reduced even further, resulting in his valuation dropping.

Other United defenders are not safe from being sold, either. Will Fish, under contract until 2025, with the option to extend for a further year, is currently on a second loan spell at Hibernian in as many seasons, meaning, with all due respect, he is never likely to make the grade at Old Trafford and become a regular under Erik ten Hag.

Brandon Williams and Alvaro Fernandez both have clauses within their contracts for additional one-year options to be triggered, meaning they could then pave the way for potential offers to come United's way, so long as suitors have already declared interest. The deal which saw Benfica sign Fernandez includes an obligation to buy if he starts 50 per cent of matches and they will pay €6m plus €3m in potential add-ons. There will still be an option to buy if the obligation isn't triggered.
Hannibal Mejbri and Donny van de Beek both departed on loan last month, joining Sevilla and Eintracht Frankfurt respectively. Each deal could be made permanent.
Though Hannibal offered flashes of his class earlier this term, he is unlikely to have a long-term future at Old Trafford. Van de Beek needs moving off the books as soon as possible.

In forward areas, Facundo Pellistri and Jadon Sancho departed on loan in the January window, potentially ending their hopes of long-term futures in M16. Sancho had been frozen out by Ten Hag since September after a public fallout.

If both players impress during their respective loans at Granada and Borussia Dortmund, this summer would represent an opportunity for United to cash in. The sales of both players would almost certainly see them record losses, though.

Mason Greenwood is still under contract at Old Trafford, meaning United need to actively try and get him off the books permanently this summer. Several clubs in Spain, including current loan club Getafe, have been linked with signing him.

Omari Forson may also be sold for a fee if United tie him down to a new contract. He is out-of-contract this summer, but the Reds, in the past, have tied a player down to a new deal and then sold them at the next available juncture.

headline: I watched Manchester United beat West Ham and saw a glimpse into a bright future
body: Here are the moments you might have missed from Man United's 3-0 win over West Ham United in the Premier League on Sunday afternoon.

Two goals from Alejandro Garnacho, both of which came in the second half, and one from Rasmus Hojlund prior to the break gave the Reds their biggest home league win of the season. United have now won each of their last two league outings, scoring seven goals in the process.

Though the victory suggested United had everything their own way, West Ham had the better of the chances in the first half. They also spurned a golden opportunity to draw level moments before Garnacho made it 2-0 at the start of the second period.

Nevertheless, United were full value for their victory over the course of the 90 minutes, inspired by eye-catching displays from Hojlund and Garnacho. The duo, particularly the latter, caused no shortage of problems for David Moyes' side, who had arrived at Old Trafford one point ahead of the Reds in the standings. Below, MEN Sport has highlighted some of the moments you may not have spotted from Sunday's encounter at Old Trafford.

Ahead of kick-off at Old Trafford, former United striker Robin van Persie was spotted back in familiar surroundings. The former Netherlands international spent three years in M16, scoring 58 goals in 105 appearances in all competitions between 2012 and 2015.

Such was the level of success he enjoyed during his time at the club, it was hardly surprising to see so many United fans sat in front of the directors' box asking him for a picture and his autograph. Van Persie kindly agreed to those requests and spent a few moments engaging with supporters. He was also in attendance at Old Trafford for the 3-2 win over Aston Villa on Boxing Day.

Though United took a slender 1-0 lead into the half-time interval, their defenders had had to deal with more than what West Ham's had in the first half. Either side of Hojlund's opener, United's back-four and keeper Andre Onana were called into action.

With 35 minutes on the clock, West Ham attempted to work the ball into the left channel of the penalty area with Emerson Palmieri latching onto a clever pass from Mohammed Kudus. But before Emerson even had chance to lift his head in the hope of picking out a man in a white shirt, Lisandro Martinez was across to greet him.

The Argentine arrived on the scene in the blink of an eye, making an excellent challenge to put the ball into touch. As soon as he was back on his feet, Diogo Dalot was slapping his flesh in a show of appreciation and celebration.

Dalot produced a tackle at Molineux on Thursday night that resulted in Raphael Varane, Onana and Martinez coming over and celebrating it like a goal. This may have been Martinez's way of returning the favour.

As Harry Maguire gave the ball away in a dangerous area, few inside Old Trafford would have anticipated celebrating a second United goal a few moments later. But after the Reds had got themselves up the pitch quickly, the majority of those inside M16 were on their feet.

Garnacho provided the all-important knockout blow, seeing a deflected effort fly past replacement West Ham goalkeeper Lukasz Fabianski. He wheeled over to the far side to celebrate the adjoining corners between the Stretford End and the Sir Alex Ferguson Stand.

Once in position, he perched himself on the edge of the advertising hoardings and was soon joined by Kobbie Mainoo and Hojlund, with the duo sitting either side of him. Each donning huge smiles, they put their arms around each other for a few seconds, no doubt savouring the smiles and happy faces all around them. We could be seeing the same celebration on show time and time again in the coming years.

After converting his second goal of the afternoon, Garnacho ran in the direction of where he had celebrated his first. Just like on the previous occasion, the youngster perched himself on the advertising hoardings.

With Mainoo off the field of play by this juncture, there was no chance of his first celebration being replicated in full. However, after being mobbed by his teammates, Hojlund embraced his fellow forward and gave him a small kiss on the cheek. It was another moment that highlighted the togetherness and spirit within the squad.

headline: Why Erik ten Hag is in a more secure position than previous Manchester United managers
body: Man United have a fine record in Saturday 12.30pm kick-offs under Erik ten Hag but West Ham away proves to be one of the toughest.
Of the Manchester United starting XI at West Ham in May, five at the very most will walk out for the Premier League anthem at the London Stadium on Saturday.
Aaron Wan-Bissaka's recall is enforced by Diogo Dalot's suspension but Marcus Rashford cannot be certain of a return. Captain Bruno Fernandes can.

The misfiring Antony is not assured of keeping his place and Christian Eriksen, back in team training this week, will likely be on the bench. Luke Shaw was in the midst of an accomplished run at centre half and Victor Lindelof was an ever-present. Tyrell Malacia has made one start since and required two rounds of surgery on his knee while Casemiro's absence with a hamstring problem is 51 days and counting.
Of the starters seven months ago, only David de Gea and Wout Weghorst have permanently left but the lack of continuity partly accounts for United's erratic form in Erik ten Hag's second season.
De Gea's flimsy attempt to repel Said Benrahma's back-pass of a shot was one of the last nails in his coffin. Ilkay Gundogan hammered in the last at Wembley a month later.
As costly as De Gea's successor, Andre Onana, has been in the Champions League, there are bigger problems up the other end. United have not scored in three games.

That last happened more recently than some may think - February and March 2021 during a stultifying streak of three goalless draws. Failure to score at West Ham would see another post-Ferguson record tumble: United have never gone four games without a goal since the Scot headed upstairs to the Old Trafford directors' box.

There are uncomfortable parallels between Ten Hag's second season and Louis van Gaal's. United have four goals fewer than they did after 17 Premier League games in that soporific 2015-16 campaign, three more defeats and a point fewer.

Only one of United's nine wins has been by more than a one-goal margin and the 3-0 defeat of Everton looks an anomaly. United were uncharacteristically clinical that day with three goals from four attempts on target: a wonder goal, a penalty and a counter-attack.

The difference between the Dutch managers is there were growing calls for Van Gaal to go during his winter of discontent. United did not win a single game out of eight in December, lost four in succession and went out at the Champions League group stage.

The tight turnaround post-Christmas of a game on Boxing Day at Stoke and against Chelsea on December 28 essentially reprieved Van Gaal. United were spirited and enterprising in a goalless draw with champions Chelsea, hitting the woodwork twice on a night United-themed Jose Mourinho scarves were sold on the Old Trafford forecourt amid the possibility of a mid-season approach.

Ten Hag does not face a similar threat. The Ineos Group's minority stake has still not been ratified at the time of writing and the sole kingmaker at a club with an interim chief executive and a football director on borrowed time is the absentee landlord Joel Glazer.

There is not an obvious and available upgrade as there was with Mourinho. The majority of United supporters would rather have Ten Hag over Graham Potter, a fine coach who oversaw magnificent progress with Brighton, but is more suited to succeeding Gareth Southgate as England manager after the European Championship.
Potter is only at the top of bookies' chalkboards as he is free. He is followed by Zinedine Zidane and Julen Lopetegui, also both out of work. Antonio Conte and Hansi Flick are also up there.

Fan power contributed to Van Gaal's downfall as thousands of season-ticket holders threatened not to renew if he remained for a third term. Ten Hag does not face a similar threat and authority to the United manager's role was restored with his appointment. Removing him would empower the minority of players looking to wait it out. The specific booing of a gaggle of players against Bournemouth was significant.

United bowed to player power by sacking Mourinho a week before Christmas in 2018. Van Gaal's methods irked several players who continued to undermine him days before the FA Cup final but the spectre of Mourinho was ample motivation not to down tools. There was also the glory of the FA Cup to play for.

Half-term reports are due after Boxing Day and it is already an unflattering look for United to have lost more games than they have won. United have a variable record at the London Stadium of three wins, three defeats and one draw. Ed Woodward later admitted the loss under Mourinho was one of the most difficult defeats he endured in September 2018.
That was also a Saturday 12.30pm kick-off.

headline: Manchester United outcast Jadon Sancho should listen to Raphael Varane's honest advice
body: Jadon Sancho's time at Man United is coming to an end after his public disagreement with manager Erik ten Hag.
There have been more recent photos of Jadon Sancho at social events than of him playing football.

Sancho has not played since August 26 and he's been on an individual training plan since falling out with Erik ten Hag, who responded to his extraordinary outburst on social media by banishing him from the squad. It's been a great shame to see a chapter of his career - the world was once at his feet - wasted over something that should have been quickly quashed, but it would be foolish to underestimate egos in football.
Although Sancho is remarkably the last United forward to have scored a home Premier League goal, he hasn't been missed and he's expected to leave in the January transfer window.

"It is about a culture and every player has to match certain standards," said Ten Hag two weeks ago. "What will happen there, he knows what he has to do if he wants to return and it is up to him. We will see what will happen."

Sancho has, rather crucially, still not apologised and that's why the stalemate with his manager has rumbled on into the winter. The player strongly believes he's not done anything wrong and he's refused to back down.

Whoever Sancho is taking advice from clearly isn't qualified to provide him with counsel. His stubbornness has cost him months of his career and it wouldn't have taken much to apologise without meaning it.

Sancho is known to be a pleasant and likeable person, from regularly engaging with fans to opening a pitch for kids where he grew up. However, there seems to be a lack of discipline in his life and Nemanja Matic recently said he was regularly late to training. There have also been timekeeping issues when he's represented England and Borussia Dortmund.

Sancho needs to address that to progress in his career, but an apology is all he needs to make right now. Yet it's clear that's not going to happen and that his ego is standing in the way of a resolution. Interestingly, Raphael Varane this week discussed the challenge of becoming an elite player in a lengthy post on LinkedIn - where he doesn't post often - and he spoke of the importance of controlling ego.

He wrote: "As someone who has played international and Champions League football, I feel extremely lucky to have done so. I also know what is required to get here. A critical element of reaching the top level is making the right decisions for yourself.

"Many of these decisions stem from ego, something that for me is one of the most important things to keep control of, and can give you a better mentality when used correctly. In football and in life, I have found that, as long as you have a strong mindset and continue to act on it, you can reach new heights.

"The accolades and recognition you get are a consequence of the decisions you make. If you focus on the process and enjoy the small improvements rather than only focusing on the result, you can always achieve great things."

It would be wrong to suggest a post from Varane was a subliminal message to Sancho but sometimes the shoe fits and it's the type of advice he should be listening to instead of refusing to apologise. Furthermore, Varane is well-placed to give such advice after falling out of favour with Ten Hag himself and seeing Jonny Evans start over him.
Varane has started the last two games against Bayern Munich and Liverpool and it would be bizarre to see him moved back to the bench in the coming weeks considering his performance at Anfield.
The Frenchman has shown Sancho how to react.

headline: I was shocked by what Manchester United did against Liverpool FC
body: Man Utd showed character to hold on and get a good point away at Anfield in the Premier League on Sunday afternoon.
If you can't win a game, then it is imperative that you don't lose. The biggest compliment you pay Manchester United is that they actually did that yesterday.

Liverpool's 7-0 thrashing earlier in the year was still very much fresh in the memory and much of the talk ahead of the match was about how many the home side would win by rather than if they would at all.

United have been hammered for the pathetic nature of some of their defeats this season, particularly against Newcastle and Bournemouth in recent weeks, and the lack of character shown on such occasions, but this time they just did enough.
This is a United side that is still relying on moments to have any joy against the very best sides and in the biggest moments at Anfield, they somehow found a way for them to turn their way.

United have been guilty of overcomplicating things under Ten Hag and trying to run before they can walk, but this was a case of keeping things simple so that they had the foundations in place to possibly nick a positive result.

It was always going to rely on a little bit of luck at the back to withstand the Liverpool bombardment and a bit of brilliance in attack for United to make the most of their infrequent forays into the opposition half. They worked for their luck, but once again their lack of experience in the forward line was glaring.

Liverpool were always going to be on top, so there was little surprise to see United adopt a defensive approach to counter it. Yet, no matter how ugly and unorthodox it was at times, they stubbornly survived with a show of real willingness and determination.

United were never going to beat Jurgen Klopp's side at their own game but they would always stand a chance if they dug deep, frustrated the home side and played the seasonal role of pantomime villains.

Andre Onana hesitated over every goalkick until the last possible nanosecond and Antony riled the home crowd with his fiery contest against Konstantinos Tsimikas. Just as important, though, was the experience of Raphael Varane and Jonny Evans at the heart of the United defence. They are the ninth different centre-back pairing used already this season, and between them, they have seen it all.

They dug deep with their defensive work and organised backline. They used every trick in the book to ruin the rhythm of the match and disrupt Liverpool from bombarding the goal in the same manner they had started the match.

But even on the rare occasions United penetrated the Liverpool backline, they lacked the composure and clinical finishing required to make the home side pay. Alejandro Garnacho took a poor touch, Rasmus Hojlund fired at Alisson Becker and Scott McTominay launched a speculative shot well wide of goal.
On another day, one of those chances might have gone in and they would have won the game. Liverpool could say exactly the same about the opportunities they somehow squandered.

That in itself is the ultimate compliment you can pay this United team. It wasn't a memorable match, but it was a memorable performance for the way they dug deep and almost nicked the match themselves.

So perhaps a draw was a fair result. Liverpool dominated but there were plenty of false dawns and for all the pressure they applied to the United goal, they still struggled to carve out any clear-cut chances to score.
It is a credit to United that Liverpool fans were the ones leaving Anfield annoyed. Now that is a shock.

headline: Eight of Erik ten Hag's 11 Manchester United signings are fighting for their places
body: Man Utd produced their best performance of the season in beating Everton with a team that looked familiar to previous eras.

It was Manchester United's best away win under Erik ten Hag but came with a heavy dose of nostalgia. Squint a little and there was more than the faint outline of an Ole Gunnar Solskjaer team in action in red at Goodison Park.

There were Victor Lindelof and Harry Maguire propelling everything thrown at them at centre-back. Scott McTominay was holding the midfield together and Marcus Rashford and Antony Martial combined in attack. There was a new man in the dugout and a new goalkeeper, but plenty of familiarity aside from that.

To give credit to Ten Hag, he has overseen the development and promotion of Kobbie Mainoo and taken Alejandro Garnacho to the next level, but his stamp on the team has become less evident as he has gone back to basics this season. After a shaky start to the season, that approach has worked with five wins out of six in the Premier League.

The 3-0 win at Everton on Sunday was the best win of the season, as well as the first statement away win of the Ten Hag era, but it came without a single Ten Hag signing starting outfield, although Andre Onana was excellent in goal. This might be close to United's best team at the moment, but it almost certainly isn't the team that their manager wants to pick.

Both Harry Maguire and Scott McTominay could have left this summer, while Mason Mount was supposed to be the final piece of the jigsaw in midfield. Ten Hag wanted his team to become more dominant in their play, but it unravelled early in the season and although injuries haven't helped, he has been forced to retreat from that ideal to get results on the board.

The question now is how he goes back to moving the team on. The win at Everton was gritty and determined, but you could argue it wasn't a team playing in the image of its manager, although injuries remain a major issue for Ten Hag.

When everyone is fit again, he might look to restore some of his signings to the team, but right now it's arguable only two more would get in alongside Onana, who after a nervous spell in goal is beginning to look like a very good signing.

If we include Sofyan Amrabat, on whom United have an option to make the move permanent, Ten Hag has signed 11 players across his three transfer windows, at a cost of more than £400million. Some were signed to play bit-part roles, such as backup goalkeeper Altay Bayindir and free agent Jonny Evans.

Maybe the same could be said for Tyrell Malacia, who is on the comeback trail after a serious knee injury, but there was an expectation he would challenge the excellent Luke Shaw and that hasn't happened. Shaw is comfortably the better player.

In the centre of defence, Lisandro Martinez would get back in this team, ahead of Lindelof and alongside Maguire, but the picture in midfield is complicated. Bruno Fernandes is undroppable and Mainoo's outstanding performance at Everton has put him in the frame for more appearances, with Scott McTominay now starting seven of the last eight games in all competitions, only missing the Carabao Cup defeat to Newcastle.

McTominay and Mainoo are starting ahead of Amrabat at the moment, with the Fiorentina loanee failing to make an impression on the team so far. Christian Eriksen had been showing some form of late, but Mount has had a difficult start to life at Old Trafford and his route back into the team looks complicated given the emergence of Mainoo.

In attack, Rasmus Hojlund will return to take the place of Martial, despite the latter's goal at Goodison Park, but Antony will surely remain on the periphery even when fit. The £85million winger has never looked like living up to that price tag and his influence on games has been minimal this season.

Ten Hag said a couple of weeks ago that Rashford would stay in the team despite his struggles for form, so having finally netted his second goal of the season his place is secure. Garnacho has also been playing well of late and after his majestic overhead kick on Sunday, there is no way he can be dropped at the moment.

So at the moment, if everyone was fit, it might only be Martinez and Hojlund that join Onana in that team. If Bayindir and Evans were signed to be reserves and you can make a case that Malacia and Eriksen were also deals to add strength to the team, it still leaves Casemiro, Mount, Amrabat and Antony on the outside.
The majority of these players would be in the team that Ten Hag wants to build at United. But for now, the approach to getting results might be leaving some of them out of favour.

headline: Sir Dave Brailsford meeting former Manchester United staff as 'brutal' changes planned
body: Changes are planned at Man United as Ineos prepare to assume control of the football operations at the club.
Sir Dave Brailsford is sounding out former staff at Manchester United as the Ineos Group prepares to make sweeping changes at the club.
Brailsford, the Ineos sporting director, is conducting thorough due diligence and a source has suggested the changes at United could be "brutal".
United sources say Brailsford has been attending meetings this month to gauge the performance challenge at United, whose title drought is certain to tick past 12 years.
Although Ineos plan to hire a sporting director and potentially a head of recruitment, the incumbent football director John Murtough wants to remain at the club.
A club source said in December it was "in the balance" as to whether Murtough stays at United or ends his decade-long association with the club.
The Manchester Evening News revealed last month Ineos are open to retaining Murtough in a more administrative role and Murtough never envisaged his role at United to centre on recruitment.

United have backed manager Erik ten Hag with investment of more than £400million on signings and sources have stressed they were tracking certain targets before the Dutchman was appointed in April 2022.
However, Murtough feels his involvement in picking players has been limited and six of Ten Hag's permanent additions played in the Eredivisie.

Brailsford and Jean Claude Blanc, the Ineos chief executive for sport, are due to join the United football board. A new chief executive could report into Blanc but it is unlikely Patrick Stewart, the interim chief executive, will stay in the role permanently.
Blanc and Brailsford accompanied Sir Jim Ratcliffe at meetings with United fan groups on Monday.

headline: Jack Fletcher is still ahead of father Darren in his development at Manchester United despite Youth Cup agony
body: Jack Fletcher and Tyler Fletcher have appeared in the FA Youth Cup and Uefa Youth League for Man United already this season and are only still 16.
"When they're on the pitch, we don't know which is which" was a chant incepted for the Da Silva twins and it could soon be allocated to the Fletchers.

Tyler and Jack were regulars in the Old Trafford directors' box last season while still in the Manchester City academy and in attendance on derby day. Amid the bedlam over Bruno Fernandes' equaliser and Marcus Rashford's winner, nobody clocked whether the teenagers dared to celebrate.

The 16-year-olds' allegiance will almost certainly have been with their father, Darren. The United technical director has to walk past the front row of journalists in the press box to take his seat with the United analysts towards the back of the Sir Bobby Charlton Stand. Occasionally, he will wave at his sons and wife Hayley.

The Fletcher twins' devotion to the red side of Manchester was confirmed when they crossed the divide to join United's academy in the summer for a combined fee of £1.25million. Should they emulate their father, they would become the 13th set of brothers to play for the United first team.

Jack and Tyler were born on the same day Cristiano Ronaldo settled an FA Cup quarter-final replay with Middlesbrough in March 2007. Darren was present for their birth as he was recovering from an ankle injury.

It was barely seven years ago that nine-year-old Jack and Tyler Fletcher were having a kickabout on the Hawthorns pitch with Kai Rooney eight days before Christmas. Darren was halfway through his final season at West Brom and soon started heading up the M6 and towards home in Manchester, spending two years with Stoke City.

Fletcher attended meetings at Old Trafford towards the end of his playing career with the intention of joining United's new structure. His return was formally confirmed in January 2021 as a first-team coach and two months later he was appointed the technical director.

If Erik ten Hag needs numbers in training on a recovery day for senior players, he or assistant Mitchell van der Gaag will consult Fletcher, who has become a conduit between the academy and the first team. Fletcher first encountered a hirsute Van der Gaag when he collected stickers for his Scottish Premiership album in the mid-90s. Van der Gaag spent two years at Motherwell.

Jack Fletcher first got the call to head across from the academy building, past the 'fountain of youth' and into the main team hub at Carrington in November. He has trained a handful of times with the first team while Tyler has started twice for the youth team.
