headline: Manchester United striker Rasmus Hojlund sends warning to Premier League rivals
body: Man United won 3-0 against West Ham in the Premier League with Alejandro Garnacho scoring twice and Rasmus Hojlund also on target
Manchester United striker Rasmus Hojlund has warned he is 'hungry' to score more goals after netting for the fourth Premier League game in a row against West Ham on Sunday afternoon.

Many felt the 4-3 victory against Wolves in midweek could be the turning point in the season and United built on that performance by securing a comfortable 3-0 win against the Hammers. Hojlund opened the scoring in the first half with an excellent finish and Alejandro Garnacho scored a brace after half-time to make sure of the result.

Hojlund spoke to MUTV after the game and made a goalscoring pledge. He said: "Reaching double figures already for such a big club is a big achievement, but I think I've said it the whole season, I'm not done. I'm hungry for more and want to keep developing, keep scoring goals, keep moving up the table and keep getting wins.

"Keep linking up with my teammates because I'm enjoying it at the moment. I think confidence is not the right word [when not scoring], you start to get a little annoyed and angry, so you lose the calmness in some situations.
"I always believed in myself, so I kept trying, and looked at my own game and what I could improve. Speaking with my teammates and the manager, asking what they see.
"We've had some talks and I've improved since I came here, so it's looking good right now. When the confidence is going, I believe I have good shots with both feet.
Hojlund was asked about playing with his attacking teammates, Marcus Rashford, Bruno Fernandes and Garnacho, and said: "A lot of excitement. Every day I come in for training and to do my job.

"I'm happy because I know I need to play with those guys, I enjoy it and you can also start seeing the connection getting good now. We're giving each other confidence and goals, involvements in the game, so I'm very happy."

headline: Manchester United have a £52million solution to defensive issue
body: Lisandro Martinez's injury has highlighted a transfer issue Manchester United will need to address in the summer transfer window
Manchester United may have believed their immediate problems at centre back were over with the return of Lisandro Martinez from injury in mid-January.

However, having suffered another setback in United’s 3-0 win against West Ham the Argentine’s injury reopened numerous questions about the future of the position at the club. Erik ten Hag still has four senior options at centre back, but with all four over the age of 30 at the start of next season, there is a need to sign a long-term option that can partner Martinez when he returns.

So, who should be the Reds' top target? Throughout Europe, there are a number of top options, including Bayer Leverkusen’s Jonathan Tah, Inter Milan’s Alessandro Bastoni and Barcelona’s Ronald Araújo.

Any of those would represent a good signing but perhaps the perfect long-term option is Sporting Lisbon's Gonçalo Inácio. The Portugal defender was heavily linked with an exit in the January transfer window, with Newcastle and Liverpool touted as possible destinations, but there was no firm offer and Inácio signed a contract extension.

The deal was a clever move by the Portuguese club to raise the 22-year-old's buyout clause to £52million, still a relatively low figure for a player of his ability. Inácio has been key to the resurgence of Lisbon under Rúben Amorim, with a league title in 2021, when Inácio was an integral member of the starting XI.

The centre back would slot seamlessly into Ten Hag’s side as the Dutchman looks to continue developing his possession-based, front-foot style of play at Manchester United. Inácio’s ability to calmly play out from the back with the ball, maintain possession, and start attacks from defence demonstrates his suitability to be an important part of the United backline.

Inácio has an outstanding ability to read the play, helping to manoeuvre him into positions to cut out dangerous attacks, while his pace and ability to perfectly time challenges help to limit the threat of attacks against his side.

Pair these abilities with the calm, reassuring nature of Inácio’s personality and this makes him a potential stalwart of any defence for years to come. While the Reds will have to wait until the summer, he is well worth the wait if United have the patience and willingness to pay his release clause.

headline: Former Manchester United player Jesse Lingard set for shock transfer
body: Former Man United player Jesse Lingard has been out of contract and he's set for a shock move to South Korea.
Former Manchester United player Jesse Lingard is set to sign for South Korean club FC Seoul.
Lingard has been without a club since the expiry of his Nottingham Forest contract at the end of last season, but he's now set to join FC Seoul in a surprise move to South Korea.

The former United player travelled to South Korea on Sunday ahead of his medical to complete his transfer. FC Seoul finished seventh in the K-League last season and their head coach, Kim Gi-dong, recently admitted that he initially thought Lingard was an unrealistic target.

He said: "I heard about it two to three weeks ago and I thought it was unrealistic. I asked our director of football about it and he replied to me, 'Yes, it's true we are in contact with the player but the deal is not confirmed yet'.

"If he comes, of course, it would be great for K-League as more foreign fans would be interested in our league. And if he comes as he was not playing for a while, we need to give him time to adapt rather than expect an instant impact.”
Lingard has since shared a photo of himself travelling to South Korea and FC Seoul are set to offer him a return to action after a spell of training without a club.
The 31-year-old trained with West Ham earlier in the season and spent time training at Saudi side Al-Ettifaq. He has also shared photos of himself training in different locations around the world.
Lingard came through United's academy and spent 11 years at Old Trafford before signing for Forest on a free transfer in the summer of 2022.
The player made 232 appearances for United and contributed 35 goals and 21 assists.

headline: Sir Alex Ferguson buys horse for Cheltenham Festival in record-breaking sale
body: Caldwell Potter has been sold for a record-breaking sum at the Tattersalls Ireland sale ahead of the Cheltenham Festival with the former Manchester United manager among the owners
Caldwell Potter has been sold for a record-breaking €740,000 (£633k) at the Tattersalls Ireland sale on Monday.

The horse will now join British champion trainer Paul Nicholls and list legendary Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson as one of his owners. Andy and Gemma Brown, who manage their horses under Caldwell Construction, shook the racing world when they announced they would sell all their horses.

Caldwell Potter was eagerly anticipated among the 29 lots set to be auctioned off at Fairyhouse. This was no doubt due to its top-rated form over obstacles for Gordon Elliott and outstanding pedigree.
The bidding began at €100,000 but dramatically escalated in a last-ditch duel between two prospective buyers. Silence filled the sales ring when a €700,000 bid was accepted.

Despite Gordon Elliot's counteroffer of €720,000, the final hammer was struck at €740,000 setting a new record for the dearest National Hunt horse ever publicly purchased. It was revealed that successful bidder was Highflyer bloodstock agent Anthony Bromley.

He begrudgingly informed Tattersalls: "I don't feel great about taking the horse out of Gordon Elliott's yard, he's done so well with the horse, but this is business and you've got to do your best for your clients.

"When I saw this horse was coming up for sale there was only one call I made and it was to John Hales. He's been a client of mine for many years, since back in the time of Azertyuiop, and we've had Neptune Collonges and Politologue in between. I bought him for a little partnership they've got together, four guys John Hales, Ged Mason, Sir Alex Ferguson and Peter Done."
"I'm thrilled to get the horse, but it is a little bittersweet because I could see how much Gordon was trying to get the horse back when he was bidding."

Caldwell Potter, a six year old son of Martaline, has shown promise, winning three times from seven starts in all and two of his first three outings over hurdles, including a Grade One success at Leopardstown's Christmas meeting. He holds entries in the Supreme Novices' Hurdle and the Baring Bingham Novices' Hurdle at next month's Cheltenham Festival, but Bromley warned he is not certain to line up in the Cotswolds.

He added: "He'll go to Paul's and he doesn't have to go to Cheltenham, I believe. It's not the be-all and end-all because it's only going to be four weeks and he has to settle into his new regime. It could be that he needs that bit of time to settle in and go to Aintree, but really we've bought him as a steeplechaser because he's got a pedigree for a Gold Cup in him, I think."

"At the moment he's only run at two miles and he's such an exciting horse for the longer term. Realistically that's why we bought him, not for four weeks' time." Caldwell Potter's fee topples the previous record set when Darren Yates bought Interconnected at an auction in Doncaster in 2019 for £620,000.

headline: 'Brighter, richer times' - National media make same prediction about three Manchester United players
body: Manchester United moved up to sixth in the Premier League on Sunday after a comfortable 3-0 win over West Ham at Old Trafford.

Rasmus Hojlund scored in a fourth consecutive Premier League with his superb strike followed by a second-half brace from Alejandro Garnacho. Erik ten Hag's team have now won three games in a row across all competitions to close the gap on the top four.
One negative note from United's win though was a potentially serious injury sustained by key centre-back Lisandro Martinez. Below is what some of the national media thought about Sunday's game...
'A straightforward and reasonably comfortable victory'

Paul Hirst of the Times wrote: "On the day when Manchester United paid their annual tribute to the victims of the Munich air disaster, it was fitting that two of their young guns stepped up to the plate and delivered the rarest of things — a straightforward and reasonably comfortable victory.

"Alejandro Garnacho, 19, scored twice and the 21-year-old birthday boy Rasmus Hojlund also got on the scoresheet as United brushed aside a wasteful West Ham United to climb above them into sixth place. Garnacho, Hojlund and Kobbie Mainoo, himself only 18, were sitting arm in arm on one of the advertising hoardings after the Argentinian’s first goal — United’s three young hopes, smiling and delivering as they try to rescue their team’s season.

"United were ruthless in attack in their third successive win in all competitions, but Lisandro Martínez, Harry Maguire and Diogo Dalot played their part too with some lion-hearted defending. Sadly for Martínez, he came off in the second half with a serious-looking knee injury after tangling with Vladimir Coufal. It was a bitter blow for the inspirational centre back, who was playing his fourth game back after a long-term foot injury."
'It was that type of afternoon for Erik ten Hag’s work in progress'

Jamie Jackson of the Guardian wrote: "This joyful United ­victory was graced by a blistering ­Rasmus Højlund strike and the comical cele­bration of Alejandro Garnacho’s first goal as he, Højlund and ­Kobbie Mainoo sat atop a Stretford End advertising hoarding.

"It was that type of afternoon for Erik ten Hag’s work in progress. On his 21st birthday, Højlund greeted his finish with a hopping air-guitar mime and a raucous cheer was provoked when, after Garnacho doubled the lead, Diogo Dalot skidded along the grass to block Jarrod Bowen’s shot.

"The low note was the sight of Lisandro Martínez, four games into returning from a foot injury, being forced off on 71 minutes with what appeared to be a knee problem. The Argentinian had played on after the clash with Tomas Soucek that seemed to cause the injury."
'No one can be quite sure what the future holds for United in the looming Ineos era'

James Ducker of the Telegraph wrote: "There may come a time, years from now, when United supporters are able to get all warm and fuzzy about the memory of three young players perched on the edge of a perimeter board – arms interlocked, wide grins on their faces – and cheerily recall those early days in the making of Alejandro Garnacho, Rasmus Hojlund and Kobbie Mainoo.

"No one can be quite sure what the future holds for United in the looming Ineos era but, amid the tangled web of problems Sir Jim Ratcliffe and the club’s new broom must unravel, there are three emerging talents there who at least offer hope of brighter, richer times ahead.

"United will mark the 66th anniversary of the Munich air disaster on Tuesday and, for a club synonymous with the fearlessness and exuberance of youth, there was something timely about the arresting impact Garnacho, Hojlund and Mainoo have made in recent days."
'The latest batch of captivating Manchester United fledglings are starting to spread their wings'

"Rasmus Hojlund only spoke of his hope he and his fellow rookies "can set an era for the club and be here many years together" on Thursday night. Here three of them were, sat together, posing in victory.

"Alejandro Garnacho mimicked West Ham winger Mohammed Kudus's signature celebration by sitting on the advertising hoarding and facing the pitch. He was joined by Hojlund and Kobbie Mainoo. United fans will hope to be watching and talking about their generation for several years."

headline: Manchester United showed just what Erik ten Hag wanted in West Ham win
body: Man Utd secured their easiest home win of the season in the Premier League as they beat West Ham 3-0 at Old Trafford.
A clinical touch

On the balance of play it's fair to say Manchester United didn't deserve to win this game 3-0. But for the first time this season, they are starting to show the clinical edge that can sometimes mark out the very best sides.

West Ham had almost twice as many shots as United and some very good chances, but they weren't efficient in front of goal and Erik ten Hag's side were. It's a ruthless side of the game we haven't seen enough this season but which is beginning to come to the fore at a valuable point of the campaign.

United have scored 15 goals in their last five games and although two of those were against teams from League One and League Two, they also scored twice against Tottenham, four times at Wolves and now three against West Ham.

The finishes produced by Rasmus Hojlund for the first and Alejandro Garnacho for the third showed how important players who can put chances away are. Maybe it's a learning curve for young players, but this side were guilty of missing too many chances earlier in the season. Now they are capitalising more often than not.

Hojlund is leading that change. His goal to open the scoring on Sunday came out of nothing. He worked the space for himself and finished brilliantly. It set an example that Garnacho followed and although this wasn't a brilliant United performance the scoreline was convincing, which has rarely been the case this season.

On countless occasions this season Ten Hag has complained about the lack of a clinical edge in his team. He even did so after the draw against Tottenham last month. He told his team they "weren't clinical enough" after the 3-3 draw with Galatasaray in Istanbul that all but ended their Champions League campaign. Finally, it looks like the message is getting through.
Martinez concerns

There were shades of Virgil van Dijk's defending against Moussa Sissoko with the way Lisandro Martinez saw off a dangerous West Ham counter early in the second half. In 2019 Van Dijk was lauded for allowing Sissoko to shoot and instead blocking off the pass to Son Heung-min, who was clearly the more dangerous player.

Martinez did exactly the same here and although he didn't touch the ball, he knew how decisive his decision-making had been when he turned to the crowd to celebrate. It was Emerson Palmieri with the chance, seizing on a loose touch from Harry Maguire to race clear in a two-on-one.
But Martinez blocked the square pass to Jarrod Bowen and forced Emerson to go on his own. His finish was befitting of a full-back who had clearly been desperate to pass.

Martinez's absence has perhaps been the most important of all for United this season, so the sight of him hobbling off in the second half left a cloud over the victory. Ten Hag's post-match diagnosis didn't sound at all encouraging.
Casemiro's contribution

Hojlund will rightly take the plaudits for the brilliance of the goal that gave United the lead, but it wouldn't have been possible without the aggressive, instinctive play that Casemiro displayed throughout last season.

The Brazilian has been a disappointment this season but since returning from an ankle injury he's shown signs of rediscovering his best form. He played a key role in the opener. He looked second favourite to reach the loose ball from Kurt Zouma's clearing header but read the game well and showed good strength to get in front of James Ward-Prowse and beat Tomas Soucek to the ball.

Casemiro made up 10 yards in very little time to slide in and touch the ball to Hojlund. And although what followed was all down to the Dane, the contribution of United's holding midfielder shouldn't be overlooked given it felt like the kind of thing he wasn't doing enough of in the first few months of the season.
Mainoo v Phillips

Kalvin Phillips made the move from Manchester City to West Ham to play the regular football he needs to cement his place in England's Euro 2024 squad, so with Gareth Southgate's assistant Steve Holland watching on at Old Trafford, the midfielder would have been disappointed to have been dropped after one game by his new club.

Phillips gave away the penalty from which Bournemouth scored in midweek and was immediately benched by David Moyes. As a former Leeds and current City player, he had to warm-up in front of the Stretford End, which went as you would expect it to.

It's been a tricky 18 months or so for Phillips since leaving his boyhood club and he was never fancied by Pep Guardiola at the Etihad. He has been a favourite of Southgate's, but his place in the England squad must be under pressure. Several youngsters are making a push for the squad and 18-year-old Kobbie Mainoo has to be at the forefront. He is now just 16 games into his senior club career but must be on Southgate's radar, especially with Ghana trying to convince the Stockport-born midfielder to represent the country of his parents.
Maguire's return

Raphael Varane's fitness record speaks for itself at United and in a way the World Cup winner had a good run starting six successive games without picking up another issue, before being benched against West Ham.

That was his longest run of starts in a row in two years and shows how badly injuries have affected his time at the club and his ability to string a run of games together. He remains a superb centre-back, but he struggles to play twice a week, has already retired from international duty and has gone public with his complaints about the schedule.

He is going to need to be rested every now and again and with Maguire back fit it made sense to rotate here, especially given Varane had played at Wolves on Thursday night. Maguire's form this season has warranted more starts.

He defended well against the Hammers in the first half. He read the game superbly early on to get to the ball ahead of Bowen and then made a superb tackle later to block Mohammed Kudus, when he was about to play Ben Johnson into acres of space down the right.

There were a couple of shaky moments after the break, gifting a big chance to Emerson Palmieri at 1-0 and then allowing a ball to go over his head to let Bowen in at 2-0. He got away with both, however, and that is maybe the difference for Maguire at the moment.

headline: Martinez, Malacia, Mount, Wan-Bissaka - Manchester United injury news and return dates
body: Lisandro Martinez picked up a knee injury for Man Utd after impressing during their 3-0 win over West Ham in the Premier League on Sunday afternoon

Manchester United are sweating on Lisandro Martinez after their World Cup-winning defender picked up a nasty-looking knee injury against West Ham on Sunday afternoon. United won the game 3-0 at Old Trafford with Rasmus Hojlund and Alejandro Garnacho (2) settling the scores in a comprehensive victory.

However, chalking up three points was not without concern. Martinez - who impressed at the back after stepping up his return from a previous setback - had to be taken off on 70 minutes after clutching his knee. Erik ten Hag said in his post-match press conference the early signs do not look good for the Argentine.
Aaron Wan-Bissaka, Tyrell Malacia, Mason Mount and Anthony Martial were all unavailable for selection. Here, we provide our latest round-up from the treatment table at Carrington;
Injury: Knee
Return date: TBC

What Ten Hag has said: "I can't say [how long], but it doesn't look good so there's a big concern, but we have to wait for the coming days what the diagnosis is then we can tell you more. We do everything to get that diagnosis to see what the damage is.

"He's very sad, very disappointed. We all really feel with him. First of all, it's a personal disaster, when it's really bad. But let's wait for what it is. For the team, also, it is really bad because he brings us a lot."
Injury: Unspecified
Possible return date: February 11 vs Aston Villa (A)
Wan-Bissaka picked up an unspecified injury before the FA Cup win over League Two opponents Newport County and has not returned to action since. He was among four players absent against West Ham.
Injury: Knee
Predicted return date: February 2024

What Ten Hag has said: "Tyrell Malacia had surgery, but he will return in quite short notice. From the New Year onwards, he can be available. We are very happy with it. Also, the others, they are working very hard to return as soon as possible."
Injury: Calf
Possible return date: February 11 vs Aston Villa (A)
What Ten Hag has said: "Mason Mount will return, but take a little longer."
Injury: Knee
Predicted return date: April 2024

What United have said: Anthony Martial has completed successful surgery to address a groin complaint and will be out of action for about 10 weeks as he rehabilitates. We wish Anthony a speedy recovery.

headline: Erik ten Hag has a problem with his world-class Manchester United partnership
body: Man Utd could make one change to their side when they host West Ham in the Premier League today.
Erik ten Hag named his strongest Manchester United side against Wolves. They still nearly managed to throw it all away.

There were certainly positives to take from the dominant performance, and on another day, it might well have been a victory by a far bigger margin, but the harsh truth is that it wasn't. It was the same story against Newport a week ago. United could have won by a three- or four-goal margin but instead, they threw away another lead when they should have been comfortable.
Yet it would still be a surprise if they chose to make any changes today. Ten Hag has regularly cited his ambition of having a settled squad, and now he has the opportunity to do just that.
It doesn't mean they shouldn't, though. See, while it might be the strongest United side on paper, there is still an argument to suggest it could be better.

United's midfield was ripped apart at ease twice in the last week, but Casemiro and Kobbie Mainoo won't be dropped, and the defence has conceded five goals in three matches when the centre-back pairing is supposed to be world-class.

Of course, keeping a clean sheet is not solely down to the centre-backs, but they are certainly a major factor. Lisandro Martinez and Raphael Varane are still widely believed to be the best two at the club, and yet the goals are still being gifted to opponents.

Martinez was off the pitch by the time Pedro Neto netted a third goal at Molineux, with Varane the unfortunate victim of United's overcommitment in the attack that left the backline exposed. There was little they could have done about the other two Wolves goals, either.

But the partnership of Martinez and Varane is still difficult to endorse due to their respective injury concerns. They have both missed a large part of the season through injuries, and the Argentine was replaced again in midweek as a precaution.

There is hope that Martinez can put his recent injury woes behind them, but the reoccurring nature of Varane's cast doubt over his long-term suitability. For all of their huge achievements—after all, they are both World Cup winners—the best ability is availability, and that is something that neither of them have nailed down this season.

Ten Hag's pursuit of consistency and momentum is being undermined by the regular changes at centre-back, and with a busy fixture schedule ahead, he needs that familiarity to stem from a settled defensive pairing.

Martinez is an integral part of the plans due to his passing ability and the different angles he opens up as a left-footer, but the plan for the summer is to sign a suitable partner for him who complements his style of play.

Varane just can't be relied upon in the long run, and Harry Maguire, who has arguably been the best-performing defender at the club this season, still doesn't seem to be the right fit for Ten Hag's desired style of play.
It is telling that now nearly everyone is available; it is Varane who has been selected over Maguire, but the real test will be keeping the Frenchman fit, which is far easier said than done.
United's defensive pairing is world-class, but only when they are actually fit.

headline: Manchester United need Alejandro Garnacho to avoid transfer embarrassment vs West Ham again
body: The early team news and main talking points as Man Utd host West Ham in the Premier League at Old Trafford today.
Manchester United will be looking to build upon their dramatic Premier League victory over Wolves when they welcome West Ham to Old Trafford on Sunday afternoon.

Erik ten Hag's side showed real character to go again after letting a two-goal lead slip in midweek, but they know they risk being punished if they don't eradicate the mistakes that so nearly cost them three points.
The return of a few more players could help United, which presents Ten Hag with a welcome conundrum as he tries to select the strongest team. Here are the main talking points:
There is more good news on the injury front, with Sofyan Amrabat and Victor Lindelof both in line to return to the squad today.

Amrabat has not played since the goalless draw with Liverpool on December 17 due to injury and his participation with Morocco at the Africa Cup of Nations. Lindelof has been sidelined since December 6 after undergoing groin surgery.
Neither of the players will go into the starting lineup, but they will at least give Ten Hag some more experienced options to call upon from the bench.
Crisis? What crisis? Rasmus Hojlund took a while to adapt to the Premier League, but now it looks like he has finally settled and will only get better.

Like all great goalscorers, the Danish forward was in the right place at the right time to score goals against Newport and Wolves, and he looks full of confidence for the first time in a United shirt.

Hojlund now has three goals and two assists across his last four appearances and is also doing a lot of the dirty work as well. Just as impressive as his goal against Wolves was a brilliant piece of hold-up play in the first half when he used a combination of silk and steel to take the ball past opposition players before unleashing a perfect pass for Marcus Rashford.
We know he can score goals in the Premier League. The next challenge is to do it on a consistent basis.
It is hard to recall any poor performances from Kobbie Mainoo in a United shirt so far. But his worst was certainly the defeat to West Ham two days before Christmas.
The 18-year-old largely looked calm and composed in possession but made a costly error when he failed to control a simple pass to set up Mohammed Kudus for the second goal of the match.
Mainoo has already come a long way since that tough afternoon at the London Stadium, and today he will be looking to prove that those mistakes really are a rarity in his rise to the top.

Speaking of that trip to the London Stadium back in December, it is hard to ignore Kudus again. It felt inevitable he would score in that meeting on a day when former teammate Antony had another performance to forget.
Of all the Ajax players Ten Hag could have signed, Kudus was arguably the one best suited to their attacking line. He cost less than half the price as well.

The Ghanaian is back from the Africa Cup of Nations and won a vital penalty for West Ham on Thursday night, shortly before Antony nearly cost his team with his careless loss of possession that led to a late Wolves equaliser.
United will hope to subdue Kudus this time around, but rather than a battle against Antony, he will have to try and outshine Alejandro Garnacho instead. It'll be a tough ask.
Garnacho has made the right-wing role his own in recent weeks and was excellent from out wide in midweek as well. Many fans would swap Kudus for Antony, but they wouldn't swap him for Garnacho.

United are unbeaten in their last 15 Premier League home games against West Ham (W12 D3), winning each of the last three 1-0. The last team to win four consecutive home games against an opponent by the same scoreline was Sunderland against Man City, who beat them 1-0 four times in a row at the Stadium of Light between 2010 and 2013.
West Ham haven't beaten United in the league at Old Trafford since their famous final-day victory in 2007. It was also the last time they completed a league double against them.

The history books certainly back United to win again today, but recent records provide plenty of doubt. West Ham have earned 17 points from their 11 away league games so far this season (W5 D2 L4), already five more than they earned on the road in the whole of last season.

Old Trafford isn't a fortress either. United have conceded seven goals in their last three Premier League home games, going down 3-0 against Bournemouth, beating Aston Villa 3-2, and drawing 2-2 with Spurs. They’ve not conceded multiple goals in four consecutive home league games since November–January 1971–72.

headline: Erik ten Hag names two Rasmus Hojlund attributes that convinced Manchester United to sign him
body: Rasmus Hojlund is starting to find his feet at Man Utd and Erik ten Hag has praised his attitude and character to keep going during a difficult season.
Erik ten Hag has praised Rasmus Hojlund's "resilience and calmness" after lauding his £72millon striker for starting to live up to the expectations he has set himself at Manchester United.

The 20-year-old endured a difficult start to his Old Trafford career in a team that was losing its way, but although the goals didn't flow for Hojlund, his attitude never changed and he never went missing.

Ten Hag revealed the striker was getting "angry and mad" as he went 14 Premier League games without a goal since his summer switch from Atalanta, but after breaking his duck against Aston Villa he has now scored in three successive top-flight games, taking his tally in all competitions to nine this season.

Hojlund has played more often than United expected this season, playing 66% of available minutes and only Andre Onana, Bruno Fernandes and Diogo Dalot have played more minutes than Hojlund's 1,911 in all competitions.

There is a feeling he has been thrown in at the deep end at United, with Anthony Martial suffering from injury and inconsistency and Hojlund taking on the mantle of starting striker when he remained relatively inexperienced, having had a rapid rise in the 18 months since FC Copenhagen sold him to Sturm Graz.
But Ten Hag is beginning to see the traits that convinced him Hojlund was the right man this summer and they are mental attributes as much as physical ones.
"I can tell you it’s not easy for a striker when you have high expectations from yourself, also the outside world has high expectations, to fulfil that when it’s not working," explained Ten Hag.
"That is the character every striker needs, he gets angry, he gets mad when he’s not scoring, but that’s why we selected him, he has the resilience and the calmness to perform under that stress.

"He doesn’t have any moment that he wants to give up, he keeps going every time to put himself in the right position. I’m happy he now starts to score, but it counts for many young players there is a lot of space for improvement, but he’s still now on very good levels."

Hojlund has scored in Premier League games against Aston Villa, Tottenham and Wolves, as well as finding the net in the FA Cup fourth-round win at Newport County. He also teed up Marcus Rashford for his redemptive opener at Molineux on Thursday and Ten Hag believes there is a partnership forming between his attacking stars.
"He is a great character, he always keeps going, always wants to improve," he said. "You see now the team is better and more stable, now we serve the front line better and he starts scoring.
"You see there is something growing with Rashy, with Garnacho, with Bruno, also other players from the second and the third line. He is coming more in a position to score."

headline: Manchester United boss Erik ten Hag 'seeks answers' as January transfer plan 'ignored'
body: Erik ten Hag is waiting to discover how much money he will be given to spend by Man United this summer as he enters the final 12 months of his contract at Old Trafford
Manchester United boss Erik ten Hag wants to know if he'll be given money to buy new players in the summer, it has been reported.

The Mirror claims that the Dutchman asked for a striker in January but 'was ignored'. It adds that despite spending £400million since leaving Ajax 18 months ago, Ten Hag feels he hasn't had enough support to change his team.
Reports from Holland suggest that Ten Hag could be in his last few months at United. When asked about a new contract beyond 2025, he didn't say anything.

United have an option to extend Ten Hag's contract and could keep him on for another year. Ten Hag thinks his team overperformed last year, finishing third in the Premier League, winning the Carabao Cup and reaching the FA Cup final.

But injuries to key players have curtailed their progress this term, while the United boss has had to deal with high-profile disciplinary issues involving Cristiano Ronaldo, Mason Greenwood, Jason Sancho and Marcus Rashford during his tenure.
The Manchester Evening News is running a survey on United's January transfer window. Let us know what YOU think below.

INEOS is set to take charge of football operations at United after Ratcliffe bought a 25 per cent stake in the club from the Glazer family for £1.3billion with the deal subject to Premier League approval. But Ten Hag was told he couldn't even bring in a player on loan last month, even though Anthony Martial was injured.

This isn't the first time Ten Hag has been left frustrated in the transfer market with United. He was upset when United didn't offer the £75million Barcelona wanted for his top target Frankie de Jong in his first summer as boss.
The club also didn't bid for Harry Kane last year, which was another blow. The England striker moved from Tottenham to Bayern Munich for £100 million.

Last year, United signed Wout Weghorst on loan from Burnley and this summer brought in Sofyan Amrabat on loan from Fiorentina. The report adds that if Bayer Leverkusen lose coach Xabi Alonso to Liverpool, they might try to get Ten Hag.
Ten Hag still has a house near the German border and became a fan of the Bundesliga when he was reserve-team coach at Bayern Munich.

headline: Manchester United have found their next Paul Pogba in the academy
body: Man Utd youngster Kobbie Mainoo is making exceptional progress and he's already been likened to Paul Pogba.

Making comparisons between established and young players is often not helpful but it's inevitable. Kobbie Mainoo has been likened to Paul Pogba and his performance for Manchester United's Under-21s against Salford City in October intensified the comparisons.

Mainoo recorded two assists and he sprayed some beautiful passes under the floodlights. His movement was reminiscent of Pogba's and the MEN's match report from that game said: "The midfielder has outgrown academy football and his talent is needed in the first-team."
Mainoo was carefully handled after his return from injury and he featured for the U21s in a handful of games, but it was only a matter of time before Erik ten Hag gave him opportunities.
The 18-year-old has been exceptional since breaking into the first-team this season and he's now one of the first names on the team sheet, which is the ultimate compliment.

Speaking last year shortly after his senior debut, someone who is close to Mainoo confidently said he would play for England and he now has an outside chance of making the Three Lions squad for this summer's European Championship after making just 12 appearances for United.
His progress has been remarkable and he possesses all the attributes to become a world-class talent, just like Pogba did when emerging from the club's academy in the late 2000s.
Pogba left on a free transfer to join Juventus in the summer of 2012 after failing to agree a new contract when it might have been advisable to build a team around him.

The Frenchman returned to Old Trafford in 2016 but his second stint wasn't a success and supporters do not remember his time in a red shirt fondly. There is no chance of Mainoo leaving on a free transfer but there is a feeling that the team should be built around him.
United have developed another special talent and he has the temperament and talent to succeed. Mainoo is understood to be quiet, likeable and kept well-grounded by his parents.

There were character issues with Pogba during his time at United and such problems with Mainoo seem highly unlikely to happen. He has the talent to eclipse Pogba's legacy in Manchester and comparisons between himself and Frenkie de Jong have also been merited.
Mainoo has operated as a deep-lying midfielder in the majority of his senior appearances, but those who know him best have suggested his long-term future will be as a No.8.
Adding goals to his game has been privately identified as an area for improvement and his two goals in two games against Newport County and Wolves show he's progressing.
Mainoo's matchwinner at Molineux gets better every time you watch it. It was a moment of individual brilliance and Rasmus Hojlund described him as a 'generational talent' after the game.

Erik ten Hag also gave him a glowing assessment. "I think very quickly I saw him," Ten Hag said. "I think last autumn I saw him for the first time and at that moment I thought he was playing a little bit too comfortable. I saw him playing in the U21s, he should be much more dominant.
"We pushed him a lot on that side, by pushing him in the training and you see he makes such good progress and he is almost progressing from game to game.
"And of course, it's wonderful to see and I hope he stays calm like he is, as he did with his goal as well. He is determined, he is a good character and I hope he keeps going with this progress."
In a separate interview with MUTV, Ten Hag added: "What he did was great, no doubt about that. He's a calm person and it looks like he grows from game to game, so hopefully he keeps this going.
"I will push and support him, but he has to do it. He has great abilities and in the future, he can be a great player. Today, we have seen it, but also in the last couple of games."
Ten Hag has a strong record of developing talent and Mainoo is at the right place to take his game to another level.
His potential is frightening and a new star from Carrington has been born. He could be everything Pogba was supposed to be for United.

headline: Erik ten Hag admits Manchester United 'headaches' and makes Champions League admission
body: Latest Manchester United news as Erik ten Hag looks ahead to United's Premier League clash against West Ham at Old Trafford on Sunday
Erik ten Hag admits that Manchester United's thrilling 4-3 win over Wolves on Thursday gave "some headaches".

Goals from Marcus Rashford and Rasmus Hojlund gave United a deserved 2-0 lead against Gary O'Neil's side before a controversial penalty decision was converted by Pablo Sarabia to make it 2-1. United then restored their two-goal cushion through Scott McTominay with a deft header.

But the hosts fought back through Max Kilman and Pedro Neto to make it 3-3 before Kobbie Mainoo's superb finish in the 97th minute sealed all three points. And Ten Hag admits the clash at Molineux should never have been a contest when United put themselves in a commanding position at half-time.

"Yeah, we were, of course, very pleased with the win," he said via the club's website. "It was a match with many stories and we are pleased with our levels - in the first hour, I would say, especially the first 45 minutes.

"But after that, we should have killed the game and we didn’t. We let them return but then the team showed character and got the win, so I’m happy for our fans. I would say it was a thriller, I think. For the neutral spectator, it was also very nice to watch this game. But for a manager, it gives some headaches."

United take on West Ham at Old Trafford on Sunday with both teams separated by just a single point. Ten Hag acknowledged the West Ham fixture will be a tricky one, with the Hammers coming into the game with a point to prove.

"Yes but it’s always about us," he said. "I always have a lot of respect and I already mentioned the qualities, the positives from West Ham United. But it’s about us - where we deliver our standards, when we bring it on the pitch, when we play as a team, then we will win the game no matter what.

"So it’s all about us, they take responsibility as a team to win the game because the fans need the win and we need the three points." And the Dutchman admits his team cannot afford to drop too many more points as they sit nine points off the top four.

"It will not be decisive for the end of the season but in the Premier League, [there are] seven or eight teams competing for those four [Champions League] positions so we can’t give points away," Ten Hag added.

"You need every point and you have to fight for every point because the points will be more expensive when you go to the end of the season, so we have to make sure, to put us in the right position in the month of February, we have to win on Sunday."

headline: Rasmus Hojlund is making Manchester United's summer transfer decision for them
body: Man Utd will look to sign a couple of forwards in the summer transfer window, and Rasmus Hojlund could influence those plans.
Erik ten Hag admits he wanted to sign another striker in the January transfer window. Rasmus Hojlund is at least easing those concerns for now.
The Danish forward took a while to adapt to the physicality of the Premier League, but now he looks right at home with goals in three successive matches.

What is most pleasing is that the last two goals in particular have been typical predatory finishes, with Hojlund in the right place at the right time to bundle the ball in from close range. He won't get much credit for those goals, but they are exactly the type United haven't been scoring in recent years.
OPINION: Mainoo has done something no other player has done under Ten Hag

Hojlund has also suffered from a lack of consistent support from his teammates so far this season, and it is no surprise his output has picked up at a time when a number of key players returned to the squad. His goal at Wolves, for example, would not have been possible without Luke Shaw in the side.

There is real excitement surrounding Hojlund at the moment, and there is real intrigue about how good he can become after such a promising run of form. Although the answer may intrigue supporters, the club's transfer committee is in dire need of finding it before the summer transfer market opens.

United are in the market for at least two forwards this summer, with Anthony Martial, Jadon Sancho, and Mason Greenwood all set to leave. Facundo Pellistri could also be sold, and Amad might need another loan move too. The jury is also very much out on Antony.
Hojlund's form in the closing months of the season will influence the type of striker United look to add to their squad, as they consider both short-term solutions and long-term additions.
There is still an argument United need another experienced option to help ease the burden on Hojlund, though signing a player currently in their prime would not be good for the player's development.

Likewise, there is also a danger of signing another relatively inexperienced and raw striker, because it could be doubling their problem rather than halving it. This would also cause the issue of trying to develop two players at the same time, something that can't really be done when they only play with one central attacker.

In an ideal world, United would add another experienced option in the same mould as previous signings Zlatan Ibrahimovic or Edinson Cavani this summer, though perhaps one who is slightly younger than those two were when they arrived, respectively.
This would give United a viable alternative to Hojlund in the forward line, but at the same time, they would not have to promise them a key role and regular starts either.

It seems like the best plan for United to reinforce their options this summer, yet in order for it to work, it relies on the Danish forward maintaining his recent level of improvement until the end of the campaign.

Based on what we have seen in recent weeks, it certainly seems a possibility, and with the United side replenished by so many returning players, he finally has the service he has been missing for so long.
Hojlund doesn't need replacing; he needs support.

headline: Kylian Mbappe could hand Manchester United transfer blow and other rumours
body: The latest Manchester United news and rumours as we take a look at two of the latest reports swirling around Old Trafford.

Reported Manchester United target Rafael Leao has been identified by Paris Saint Germain as a potential replacement for Kylian Mbappe, according to ESPN. Mbappe is out of contract with the French giants in the summer and a decision is yet to be made over his future.

He has been heavily linked with a move to Real Madrid. If that’s the case, Leao has been identified as a ‘replacement’ by PSG. United were linked with an interest in the AC Milan forward back in November.
Leao only signed a new five-year deal in June meaning that Milan are expected to ask for a big fee. Manchester City have also been linked with an interest in the 24-year-old.

It is claimed that the forward has a release clause of €175 million in his contract, although clubs could try to negotiate a lower fee. His numbers have not been so good this season, having scored six goals in 26 outings.
In other news, Erik ten Hag’s future at United could depend on how much money he is given to spend in the summer transfer window, reports have suggested.

There has been speculation over his future at Old Trafford following the takeover by INEOS. When the summer comes around he will have one year remaining on his current deal after taking over in the summer of 2022, United do have the option of triggering a 12-month extension last year.

The Mirror now suggest that the United boss has been left ‘frustrated’ by being unable to make a loan signing in the January transfer window, despite losing Anthony Martial to injury. The report adds that he feels there has been a ‘lack of consistent backing’ in the transfer market for him to put his own stamp on the squad.

It is said that Ten Hag ‘wants answers’ on whether he will be given money to spend on new signings when the summer transfer window opens United have spent around £400 million on new arrivals since Ten Hag has been in charge.

headline: Manchester United ‘make’ Kobbie Mainoo contract decision plus more transfer rumours
body: Mainoo has been one of Man United's standout players this season and might soon be rewarded for that.
Manchester United are reportedly set to hand Kobbie Mainoo a new and improved contract following his sensational performances this season.

The 18-year-old signed a fresh deal last February following his first-team debut a few weeks earlier. Mainoo has grown immensely since then and has become an important starting XI figure despite his tender age.

He grabbed his first Premier League goal with a dramatic 97th-minute winner against Wolves on Thursday after another impressive showing. Mainoo’s current deal runs until 2027 but could soon have his stay extended. The academy graduate will not be offered new terms before the summer in a bid to avoid distraction from his on-field form.

That’s according to the Daily Mail, which adds that Erik ten Hag now views him as an established first-team star and will hand Mainoo fresh terms at the end of the season to ward off any transfer interest.

Mainoo returned from a serious pre-season ankle injury in November to tally 12 senior appearances so far this term The teenager has started the last six Premier League matches, which stretches to eight when FA Cup ties are factored in.

Meanwhile, a report from HITC claims that Borussia Dortmund star Sebastian Haller was offered to United in January. Ten Hag revealed last week that the club had “no space” for new arrivals, even loans, amid Financial Fair Play concerns.

Haller, who has two goals in 14 outings, has Premier League experience having played for West Ham between 2019 and 2021. United, who have just lost Anthony Martial for two months after groin surgery, are after attacking reinforcements but would not have been able to afford 29-year-old Haller, no matter the price.

headline: Shola Shoretire faces uncertain Manchester United future despite contract wish
body: Man Utd hope Shola Shoretire signs a new contract but he might not have many more first team chances.
Shola Shoretire faces an uncertain future at Manchester United after dropping down the pecking order, even though the club is hoping he signs a new deal.
The academy graduate celebrated his 20th birthday on Friday and is now at an awkward crossroads where he is untested at youth level and needs to be playing regular football at senior level.

Shoretire made his first-team debut at the age of just 17 and still holds the record as the youngest player to represent United in European competition. However, he has struggled to build upon that early promise and has been overtaken in the pecking order by other academy graduates.
LATEST: £150m trio to be removed from Premier League squad after January transfer window
He has trained with the first team consistently in recent weeks and more often than he has at any other point of the season. Yet he has been overlooked.

Kobbie Mainoo was the match winner in midweek, a goal that was set up by fellow academy product Omari Forson. They, along with Alejandro Garancho, are the hottest young talents at the club, while Willy Kambwala has also been given opportunities this season.
Shoretire's struggles are a reminder of the cutthroat nature of academy football. A homegrown talent at a club like United is the next best thing until another soon emerges to take their place.

Erik ten Hag has taken on a more hands-on approach with the academy since he joined the club, having felt the U21s were 'isolated' before his arrival. He now takes an active role in deciding which youngsters train with the first team and has set the challenge for at least one youth team player to become part of the first team during every season he's at the club.

The United manager won't give youngsters an opportunity just to keep up traditions, and he has made it clear that only the very best youth prospects will be given a chance in the senior set-up. Mainoo and Garnacho fit the criteria as elite talents; Shoretire should not be ashamed that he doesn't quite fit that bracket anymore.

United are in preliminary talks with Shoretire over a new contract and still hope he agrees to new terms, as they look to protect his value in the increasingly likely scenario where he is sold in the coming years. A loan move was mooted in the January transfer window but never materialised.

While the primary task of the club's illustrious academy is to produce talent for the first team, United also accept that it can be a money-making machine. With current Financial Fair Play rules, it is hugely beneficial to a club to sell homegrown players because the profit on the sale is purely classified as income.

Isak Hansen-Aarøen was sold on deadline day, while Hannibal Mejbri moved to Sevilla on an initial loan with the option of a permanent sale, and Alvaro Fernandez left in a similar deal to join Benfica. Anthony Elanga, Zidane Iqbal, Matej Kovar, Teden Mengi, Axel Tuanzebe, Ethan Laird, Charlie Savage, Noam Emeran, and Marc Jurado were all allowed to leave last summer.
It would make sense if Shoretire was one of the next to join them in exiting the club. He has shone brightly at times, but now it looks to be in the interest of all parties if he were moved on too.
The academy not only makes world-class talent, it makes money as well.

headline: Four Manchester United players leave on loan deals
body: Man United have developed innovative loan moves for their players and four players have made switches on January transfer deadline day.
Manchester United youngsters Sam Mather, Sam Murray, Sonny Aljofree and Tom Wooster have signed innovative loan deals.
United created a flexi-loan system last season, which allows youngsters to gain senior experience whilst remaining involved in the day-to-day environment at Carrington.

⁠Sam Mather (Rochdale), Sam Murray (Rochdale), Sonny Aljofree (Altrincham) and Tom Wooster (Macclesfield) are the latest to sign such deals. They have all joined Greater Manchester clubs and United believe that is further evidence of the academy's support of local football.
The initiative will enable all four players to play senior football whilst still having the opportunity to play for and train with the academy.
It's understood the youngsters will benefit from a bespoke and flexible programme, with coaches able to make decisions on their schedule week-by-week.
Mather, 19, recently returned from a long-term injury and he scored four goals for the Under-21s against Norwich last weekend. He will spend time with Rochdale.
Murray, 19, will also gain experience with Rochdale. Mather and Murray were both part of the Under-18 side that won the FA Youth Cup in the 2021/22 season.
Maxi Oyedele, Joe Hugill and Aljofree were the first players to leave United as part of the innovative scheme last year. Aljofree spent time with Altrincham and he's re-signed for the club.
Goalkeeper Wooster, 18, joins Macclesfield after having a traditional loan stint with Ramsbottom United last term.

headline: Manchester United Under-18s continue flawless league record with victory against Liverpool
body: Man United's Under-18s have been in excellent form this season and they still have a flawless record in the league.
Manchester United Under-18s extended their flawless league record with a 4-3 win against Liverpool on Tuesday night.
The youngsters have taken their division by storm and their victory over Liverpool means they have won all 14 of their games.
Ethan Wheatley, Jayce Fitzgerald, Ethan Williams and James Scanlon all got on the scoresheet and United went behind twice before fighting back to win the match.
The result also extended the U18s' lead at the top of the table by 17 points. United last won the U18 league in 2017/18 and they could wrap up the title in the coming weeks.
Manchester City's U18s won the title last season and they currently sit second in the table. They have two games in hand over United.
United were expected to go deep in the FA Youth Cup this term and they were stunned when being knocked out of the competition by Swindon Town earlier this month.

Adam Lawrence took charge of the U18s in the summer and he spoke to the MEN before Christmas. "Young players are competitive individuals - they want to win games, they want to perform at a good level," he said when asked about the flawless league run.

"I think it's testament to the group that since pre-season, you've seen the development and the way that the team has evolved up until now, the individual development within that and then the style and some of the football the lads have played.
"There's a lot to go after in terms of the bigger picture, but a lot of like really good moments in games as well so far."

headline: Manchester United starlet scores four goals in Old Trafford win including 15-minute hat-trick
body: Man Utd U21s thumped Norwich at Old Trafford and one youngster caught the eye with a remarkable hat-trick.
In a season largely of disappointment for Manchester United, their youth teams continue to be a beacon of light to be proud of.

On Saturday lunchtime, the U18s made nine changes to their side and still thrashed Leeds to maintain their flawless start to the new campaign with 13 wins from 13. A couple of hours later, the U21s continued where they left off with an emphatic victory over Norwich at Old Trafford.

United are well aware that positive results are simply a by-product of all the hard work that goes on at the youth level, and the real success of their illustrious academy is that 249 players have emerged from it to make their competitive debuts for the club.
MOST READ: Sevilla issue Hannibal statement after he is made unavailable for selection

A week after United held their annual academy event at Old Trafford, it was the turn of the U21s to showcase why they should be the next in line to get a first-team opportunity. Head of the Academy, Nick Cox, said he was genuinely intrigued to know who the next would be. It might not be Sam Mather, but he could well be one of the following crop to do so.

The 19-year-old was one of the key players when United won the FA Youth Cup two years ago, scoring two goals on their road to the final. Two of his teammates from that side, Kobbie Mainoo and Alejandro Garnacho, are now shining for the first team. He has every right to dream of that himself.

Mather's progress has been halted by injury since that youth team triumph and now he looks to be making up for lost time. It only took him fifteen minutes to net a stunning first-half hat-trick on Saturday afternoon.
Those memorable nights in the Youth Cup had Mather well used to playing at Old Trafford and he looked right at home when he calmly fired in at the back post to give his side an early lead.

He almost had a second when his low shot was saved by Dan Barden, but the Norwich 'keeper could do nothing about his next effort when United won a free kick about 25 yards out from goal and Mather expertly fired it into the top right corner of the goal.

It means a lot to the Salford-born winger to get these opportunities and even more that he has been able to take them. Five minutes after his stunning free kick, he fired another low effort just wide of goal from outside the box.

What will please his coaches most, though, is that he also knows how to do the simple stuff. If you put yourself in the right areas, you will score a lot of goals. He did just that when he tapped in a third from a matter of yards out after James Scanlon's initial effort had been saved.

He not only had three goals in 15 minutes, but he could quite easily have had five. But if you don't take those chances, you will be punished. Norwich didn't have many but got one back on the stroke of half time when Ken Aboh fired into the bottom corner after a brilliant solo run.

Norwich were much improved after the restart but when a player is in red-hot form, there is little you can do. United worked the ball well on the edge of the box and when it reached Mather at the back post, he cut inside and curled a beautiful effort into the far corner of the net.

The only annoyance is that United's dominance wasn't so obvious by the end. A calamitous defensive mix-up allowed Adian Manning the simplest of tap-ins into an open net and Norwich should have had another when Aboh fired over from a tight angle inside the box.
In a month when United sources claim any move for a new forward would have to be "exceptionally economical," there would be no greater example than promoting someone from the youth ranks instead.
United are in desperate need of another goal-scoring forward. Mather is one of them.

headline: Manchester United youngster Dan Gore explains Port Vale loan decision
body: The 19-year-old midfielder will spend the rest of the season at the League One club, and has explained why Port Vale was the place that attracted him the most for his loan spell
Manchester United midfielder Dan Gore has spoken about his loan move to Port Vale and why he chose the League One side as his home for the rest of the season.

A number of clubs, including Preston and Bolton Wanderers, had expressed an interest during this month's transfer window in taking the 19-year-old on board, but - with guidance from his father - it was the Potteries side that won the day and he could make his debut this weekend against Portsmouth.
The MEN reported yesterday how United had agreed on Port Vale as Gore's destination because of the way they play and their support system for young players.
He said: "Well, I think from the first time I've come here to see the place and meet everyone, I just knew straight away. Because I got a feeling it's just like a family. Everyone was very welcoming.
"I've obviously seen Port Vale play and they play very good football.

"My dad was shocked. He was like: 'Son, you've got to go there'. He just knew they'd take care of me and obviously, at this stage of my career, I need that because I'm still developing. He knew, straight away, he got the best feeling from here."

Gore is friends with Vale's Manchester-born midfielder Tommy McDermott, who also urged him to agree to the switch, and he'll also see familiar faces there in the guise of ex-Reds Tom Sang and James Wilson.
"Tommy said definitely go, it'll be the best experience for you," added Gore. "You'll develop really well.
"I can guarantee hard work and determination to do everything for the badge; to do our best to try to get the three points in every game. The most important thing is winning.
"I trained Monday and Tuesday and they went really good. I trained hard and am looking forward to keeping going."

headline: Manchester United 'considering options' after controversial cup exit following Aston Villa error
body: Manchester United will not progress to the last eight of the Continental League Cup as a result of the FA punishing Aston Villa Women, but not expelling them from the competition altogether

Manchester United say they are "very disappointed" and are 'considering their options' following an FA ruling which has seen them dumped out of the Continental League Cup as a result of Aston Villa's administrative error.

The Reds' 2-1 defeat to Manchester City last week saw them finish second in Group B, with their otherwise exemplary record in this season's competition meaning they were set to advance to the last eight as one of two best-placed runners-up. However, Aston Villa's decision to field January signing Noelle Maritz in their 7-0 win over Sunderland has had a knock-on effect on Marc Skinner's side, who will now not progress to the knockout stages.

Maritz, who moved to Bescot Stadium from Women's Super League (WSL) rivals Arsenal earlier this month, was introduced in the second half against Sunderland, despite already being cup-tied. She had featured three times for the Gunners in the competition earlier in the season, starring against Bristol City, Southampton and Tottenham Hotspur.
READ | Major Morgan Rogers to Aston Villa transfer update as third bid tabled
READ |  Tielemans starts, Bailey returns - Aston Villa starting XI vs Newcastle picked

As a result, her introduction against Sunderland was in breach of Conti Cup rule 8.14 - which deals with the fielding of an ineligible player - and the points for the contest have instead been awarded to the Black Cats. An FA statement released on Monday said: "An independent tribunal have deducted three points from Aston Villa for fielding an ineligible player during their FA Women’s Continental Tyres League Cup group stage fixture against Sunderland on Wednesday 24 January 2024.

"The FA alleged that the player was ineligible for this game, as she had previously featured in the competition for her former club, which constitutes a breach of Cup Rule 8.19. Aston Villa admitted this charge and acknowledged the breach had occurred. The independent tribunal ordered that the points deducted from Aston Villa be awarded to their opponents Sunderland, while the 7-0 scoreline is to be expunged from the record.
"As a result, Sunderland will finish as Group A winners, with Aston Villa progressing to the quarter-finals as one of the two best-placed runners-up alongside Tottenham Hotspur."

Responding to the news, a Manchester United spokesperson said: "We are very disappointed with this outcome and do not understand its rationale. We feel that it undermines the integrity of the competition and of the women's game. We are considering our options in response."
United have won three of their four games in the Conti Cup this term, beating Everton 7-0, Liverpool 1-0 and Leicester City 3-1.
